Unless otherwise indicated, statements in this offering memorandum regarding the market environment, market developments, growth rates, market trends and the competitive situation in the markets and segments in which we operate are based on data, statistical information, sector reports and studies as well as on our own estimates. In drafting this offering memorandum, we used industry sources and sources on market data, including reports prepared by GfK SE (‘‘GfK’’), the International Monetary Fund (the ‘‘IMF’’), the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (the ‘‘OECD’’), Eurostat, Notarisbarometer and Statistics Netherlands (CBS). To the extent that information was taken from third parties, such information has been accurately reproduced by us in this offering memorandum and, as far as we are aware and able to ascertain from the information published by these third parties, no facts have been omitted which would render the reproduced information inaccurate or misleading. Market data are inherently forward-looking and subject to uncertainty, and do not necessarily reflect actual market conditions. They are based on market research, which itself is based on market data sampling and judgments by the researchers about what types of products and competitors should be included in the relevant market. We have not verified the figures, market data and other information used by third parties in the studies, publications and financial information reproduced herein, or the external sources on which our estimates are based. We therefore assume no liability for and offer no guarantee of the accuracy of the data from studies and third-party sources contained in this offering memorandum or for the accuracy of third-party data on which our estimates are based. This offering memorandum also contains estimates of market data and information derived from such data that cannot be obtained from publications by independent sources. Such information is partly based on our own market observations, the evaluation of industry information (such as from conferences and sector events) or internal assessments. We believe that our estimates of market data and the information we have derived from such data helps investors to better understand the industry in which we operate and our position within it. Our own estimates have not been checked or verified externally. While we assume that our own market observations are reliable, we give no warranty for the accuracy of our own estimates and the information derived from them. They may differ from estimates made by our competitors or from other independent sources. While we are not aware of any misstatements regarding the industry or similar data presented herein, such data involves risks and uncertainties and are subject to change based on various factors, including those discussed under the heading ‘‘Risk Factors’’ in this offering memorandum. As a result, neither we nor the Initial Purchasers make any representation as to the accuracy or completeness of any such information in this offering memorandum. ix -----

Subsection Title: U.S. dollar per g1.00 High** **Low** **Average** **Period End Year

Subsubsection Text: The following tables set forth, for the periods set forth below, the high, low, average and period-end Bloomberg Composite Rate expressed as U.S. dollar per e1.00. The Bloomberg Composite Rate is a ‘‘best market’’ calculation, in which, at any point in time, the bid rate is equal to the highest bid rate of all contributing bank indications and the ask rate is set to the lowest ask rate offered by these banks. The Bloomberg Composite Rate is a mid-value rate between the applied highest bid rate and the lowest ask rate. The rates may differ from the actual rates used in the preparation of the consolidated financial statements and other financial information appearing in this offering memorandum. None of the Issuer, the Guarantors or the Initial Purchasers represent that the U.S. dollar or euro amounts referred to below could be or could have been converted into U.S. dollars at any particular rate indicated or any other rate. The average rate for a year, a month or for any shorter period, means the average of the daily Bloomberg Generic Rates during that year, month or shorter period, as the case may be. On September 11, 2020, the exchange rate between the U.S. dollar and the euro was $1.1837 per e1.00.

In this offering memorandum, the following words and expressions have the following meanings, unless the context otherwise requires or unless otherwise so defined. In particular, capitalized terms set forth and used in the sections titled ‘‘Description of Other Indebtedness—Intercreditor Agreement’’ and ‘‘Description of the Notes’’ may have different meanings from the meanings given to such terms and used elsewhere in this offering memorandum. References to: - ‘‘Agreed Security Principles’’ are to the ‘‘Agreed Security Principles’’ as set forth in an annex to the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, as in effect on the Issue Date, as _applied mutatis _mutandis with respect to the Notes in good faith by the Issuer._ - ‘‘Ardian’’ are to funds, limited partnerships, investment vehicles and/or accounts managed or advised by Ardian France S.A., a limited company (soci´et´e anonyme), organized and established under the laws of France, and its affiliates. - ‘‘Authority’’ are to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited. - ‘‘Belgian DIY Market’’ are to the Belgian DIY market as defined by GfK, with market share data based on the total store sales of Brico, BricoPlanit, Gamma, Hubo and Mr. Bricolage, the five largest Belgian DIY retailers. - ‘‘Benelux’’ are to Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, collectively. - ‘‘CAGR’’ are to the compound annual growth rate, calculated by subtracting one to the difference between the final value and the initial value raised to the power of one divided by the number of years lapsed. - ‘‘Cash Flow Conversion’’ are to Adjusted EBITDA less maintenance capital expenditure divided by Adjusted EBITDA. - ‘‘Change in Like-for-Like Sales’’ are to the change in Transactional Sales for Like-for-Like Stores during the relevant period-over-period under comparison. - ‘‘Click & Collect’’ are to a service whereby customers can order products that require assembly from a store’s website and collect them from the store after assembly by our specialists. - ‘‘Click & Reserve’’ are to a service whereby customers can order products that do not require assembly from a store’s website and collect them from the store. - ‘‘Collateral’’ have the meaning set forth under ‘‘Summary—The Offering—Security.’’ - ‘‘COVID-19’’ are to the disease caused by a novel strain of coronavirus SARS-CoV-2. - ‘‘DIY’’ are to do-it-yourself, the activity of decorating, repairing or improving one’s home oneself, rather than employing a professional. - ‘‘Drop Shipment Model’’ are to a delivery model whereby a website transfers customer orders and shipment details to either the supplier or a wholesaler of the product ordered by the customer, who then ships the product directly to the customer. - ‘‘Dutch DIY Market’’ are to the Dutch DIY market as defined by GfK, based on the total store sales of DIY superstores, paint specialists and other DIY retailers in the Netherlands. - ‘‘Dutch DIY Superstores Market’’ are to the Dutch DIY superstores market as defined by GfK, with market share data based on the total store sales of Praxis, Gamma, Karwei, Hornbach, Bauhaus, Hubo and Multimate. - ‘‘Exchange’’ are to The International Stock Exchange. - ‘‘Existing Notes’’ are to the Issuer’s e475 million 6[1]⁄8 Senior Secured Notes due 2022 issued under an indenture entered into on July 13, 2017, by and among, _inter alios, the Issuer, the Trustee and the Security Agent. The Issuer repurchased e40 million of Existing Notes during the six months ended August 2, 2020, and the remaining e435 million will be redeemed in full pursuant to the Refinancing. xi ----- - ‘‘Existing Notes Redemption’’ are to the redemption of the entire aggregate outstanding principal amount of the Existing Notes, which is expected to occur on or around the Issue Date. - ‘‘Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement’’ are to the e50.0 million revolving credit facility agreement entered into July 13, 2017, as amended and restated by an amendment and restatement agreement on July 19, 2017, and the facility made available thereunder is referred to as the ‘‘Existing Revolving Credit Facility’’, which will be terminated on or around the Issue Date in connection with the Refinancing. - ‘‘EU’’ are to the European Union. - ‘‘euro’’ or ‘‘e’’ are to the lawful currency of the European Monetary Union. - ‘‘GoldenTree Asset Management’’ are to GoldenTree Asset Management L.P. and its affiliates and, where applicable, the funds, limited partnerships and/or accounts managed or advised by them. - ‘‘Gross Profit Margin’’ are to gross profit for a certain period divided by the revenue for such period. - ‘‘Guarantees’’ are to, collectively, the guarantees of the Notes on a senior basis by the Guarantors. - ‘‘Guarantors’’ are to, collectively, Maxeda DIY, Praxis Groep B.V., Praxis Doe-het-Zelf Center B.V., Brico Belgium NV, PLAN-IT NV and Brico Plan-It NV, as guarantors of the Notes, and ‘‘Guarantor’’ refers to each of them. - ‘‘IFRS’’ are to International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union. - ‘‘Indenture’’ are to the indenture to be entered into on or about the Issue Date governing the Notes, by and among, inter alios, the Issuer, the Trustee and the Security Agent. - ‘‘Intercreditor Agreement’’ are to the intercreditor agreement to be entered into on or about the Issue Date between, among others, the Issuer, the Guarantors, the Security Agent, the facility agent with respect to the Revolving Credit Facility on behalf of the lenders thereunder and the Trustee. - ‘‘Issue Date’’ are to, 2020. - ‘‘Issuer’’ are to Maxeda DIY Holding B.V. - ‘‘Like-for-Like Sales’’ are to Transactional Sales from Like-for-Like Stores during the relevant period-over-period under comparison. - ‘‘Like-for-Like Stores’’ are to those directly operated stores and franchisee-operated stores that were, in each case, in operation for not less than one year prior to the year or interim period for which Like-for-Like Sales or Change in Like-for-Like Sales, as applicable, is being measured. - ‘‘maintenance capital expenditure’’ are to ordinary course capital expenditures primarily consisting of repairs, purchases of fixtures and fittings, and expenses in connection with the refurbishment of our existing directly operated stores, range reviews and IT. - ‘‘Maxeda DIY’’ are to Maxeda DIY B.V. - ‘‘Maxeda DIY Group’’ are to Maxeda DIY Group B.V. - ‘‘Maxeda DIY Intercompany Loan’’ are to the intercompany loan dated June 29, 2007, as amended from time to time, between Maxeda DIY as lender and the Issuer as borrower. - ‘‘Notes’’ are to the e400 million aggregate principal amount of % Senior Secured Notes due 2026 offered hereby. - ‘‘Offering’’ are to the offering of the Notes as described in this offering memorandum. - ‘‘Operational Cash’’ are to cash in tills and cash in transit, which is recorded as part of cash and cash equivalents on our statement of financial position. - ‘‘private label products’’ are to products provided by us under brands that we own. - ‘‘Refinancing’’ are to the transactions described in ‘‘Summary—The Refinancing.’’ xii ----- - ‘‘Revolving Credit Facility Agreement’’ are to the e65 million revolving credit facility agreement to be entered into on or around the Issue Date and as described more fully under ‘‘Description of _Other Indebtedness—Revolving Credit Facility Agreement,’’ and the facility made available_ thereunder is referred to as the ‘‘Revolving Credit Facility.’’ - ‘‘Security Agent’’ are to U.S. Bank Trustees Limited, as security agent under the Intercreditor Agreement, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Indenture. - ‘‘Security Documents’’ are to agreements creating security interests over the Collateral for the Notes as described under ‘‘Description of the Notes—Security—Security Documents.’’ - ‘‘SKU’’ are to stock-keeping unit. - ‘‘Sponsors’’ are to, collectively, Ardian and GoldenTree Asset Management. See ‘‘Principal _Shareholders.’’_ - ‘‘Store Home Delivery Model’’ are to a delivery model whereby a customer orders a product on our website and such product is delivered directly from the store to the customer at their preferred shipping address. - ‘‘SITI program’’ are to our store inventory turn improvement program aimed at structurally decreasing stock and improving working capital. - ‘‘Third-party branded products’’ are to products produced by third parties that bear brands owned or licensed by them. - ‘‘Transactional Sales’’ are to the value of sales to the end-consumer (including online sales and sales by our directly operated stores and franchisee-operated stores) and value added tax. - ‘‘Trustee’’ are to U.S. Bank Trustees Limited as trustee under the Indenture. - ‘‘United States’’ or ‘‘U.S.’’ means the United States of America, its territories and possessions, any State of the United States of America and the District of Columbia; - ‘‘U.S. dollars’’ or ‘‘$’’ are to the lawful currency of the United States. - ‘‘we,’’ ‘‘us,’’ ‘‘our’’ and the ‘‘group’’ are to the Issuer and its consolidated subsidiaries, unless the context otherwise requires. xiii -----

The following cautionary statements identify important factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements made in this offering memorandum. Any statements about our expectations, beliefs, plans, objectives, assumptions or future events or performance are not historical facts and may be forward looking. These statements are often, but not always, made through the use of words or phrases such as ‘‘will likely result,’’ ‘‘are expected to,’’ ‘‘will continue,’’ ‘‘believe,’’ ‘‘anticipated,’’ ‘‘estimated,’’ ‘‘intends,’’ ‘‘expects,’’ ‘‘plans,’’ ‘‘seek,’’ ‘‘projection’’ and ‘‘outlook.’’ These statements involve estimates, assumptions and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in them. Any forward-looking statements are qualified in their entirety by reference to the factors discussed throughout this offering memorandum. Important risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause such differences between the actual results from those expressed in forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to: - competitive forces in the markets in which we operate; - our ability to identify, anticipate and accurately predict and address customer preferences, demand and demographics; - general economic conditions (including GDP growth, unemployment rates and inflation), the health of the housing markets, consumer confidence, spending patterns and other trends in consumer behavior, particularly in the Belgian and Dutch markets; - harm to our brand image or reputation; - our ability to attract, train and retain highly qualified and motivated employees; - our ability to optimize our operational efficiency in accordance with our strategy and realize the related cost savings; - risks associated with our franchise ownership structure; - our ability to acquire and maintain necessary permits and licenses; - risks associated with our predominantly leasehold property portfolio, including our exposure to variations in rental costs and our ability to obtain favorable lease terms; - interruptions at our warehouses and distribution facilities or disruptions to our existing supply chain; - our business’s susceptibility to sustained periods of unfavorable weather; - our ability to successfully grow our digital platform; - interruptions or failures of our information technology and/or information technology systems; - the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business; - our capability to successfully implement our expansion strategy; - the ineffectiveness of our advertising and marketing programs; - our ability to protect and enforce our intellectual property rights; - our ability to protect the confidentiality of our proprietary information and know-how; - risks associated with our relationships with third-party suppliers; - our ability to manage and expand our alliances and relationships with selected suppliers and risks associated with the global sourcing of our product offering; - negative public perceptions of us or our suppliers; - variations in the prices of raw materials and energy; - natural disasters, public health crises, political crises or other catastrophic events outside our control; - increased transportation costs and disruption of transportation services; xiv ----- - changes in credit and debit card provider requirements or applicable regulations which may adversely affect our business; - shop crime and fraud in our stores; - our ability to protect the privacy and security of personal and confidential information; - our dependence on management and key personnel; - potential prolonged disruptions of business operations due to work stoppages or strikes; - legal and regulatory risks; - adverse changes in tax laws or their application or interpretation, or adverse results of current or future tax audits or investigations with respect to tax liabilities; - increases in the rate of value added tax or other applicable tariffs; - fluctuations in currency exchange rates and inflation; - risks associated with our ability to access liquidity and credit; - compliance with applicable competition and antitrust laws; - risks associated with interruptions or failures of our information technology and/or customerfacing technology systems; - complaints and litigation; - product liability claims and product recalls; - our ability to recover from our third-party suppliers with respect to defective merchandise and unsatisfactory services; - insufficient insurance coverage; - requirements to increase our pension fund contributions; and - potential conflicts of interest between our current or future controlling shareholders and the holders of the Notes. These and other factors are discussed in ‘‘Risk Factors’’ of this offering memorandum. Because the risk factors referred to in this offering memorandum could cause actual results or outcomes to differ materially from those expressed in any forward-looking statements made in this offering memorandum by us or on our behalf, you should not place undue reliance on any of these forward-looking statements. Furthermore, any forward-looking statement speaks only as of the date on which it is made, and we undertake no obligation to update any forward-looking statement to reflect events or circumstances after the date on which the statement is made or to reflect the occurrence of unanticipated events. New factors will emerge in the future, and it is not possible for us to predict such factors. In addition, we cannot assess the impact of each factor on our business or the extent to which any factor, or combination of factors, may cause actual results to differ materially from those described in any forward-looking statements. xv -----

We are a leading DIY retailer in Belgium and the Netherlands. For the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, we had the largest combined share of the Belgian DIY Market through our Brico and BricoPlanit brands, with a market share of approximately 44% of the Belgian DIY Market based on Transactional Sales. In the Netherlands, we estimate that we had the second largest combined share of the Dutch DIY Superstores Market through our Praxis brand, with a market share of approximately 25% based on Transactional Sales. Our store portfolio consists of directly operated stores and franchisee-operated stores trading under three store brands: Brico, BricoPlanit, and Praxis. As of August 2, 2020, our store portfolio included 348 stores (including 121 franchisee-operated stores), comprising 195 stores in the Netherlands under our Praxis brand and 150 stores in Belgium and three stores in Luxembourg under our Brico and BricoPlanit brands. During the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, our directly operated stores (including Click & Collect) accounted for 83% of our revenue, our franchisee-operated stores accounted for 15% of our revenue and our online sales (excluding Click & Collect) accounted for 2% of our revenue. An overview of our store brands is set forth below: Brico:_** We directly operate 60 stores in Belgium and three stores in Luxembourg, and our franchisees operate 77 stores in Belgium under the _Brico brand and the_ _Briko Depot and_ _Brico City sub-brands. Established in 1973, Brico is the DIY market leader in Belgium, with a market share of approximately 29% in the Belgian DIY Market in terms of Transactional Sales for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, according to GfK. Brico offers a wide range of DIY, home decoration and garden products with 28,000 to 50,000 SKUs stocked per store. The average floor surface area of our directly operated Brico stores is approximately 3,300 square meters and the average floor surface area of our franchisee-operated Brico stores is approximately 1,800 square meters. Brico’s three largest product groups are paint, paint specialties and accessories, and hardware. Brico accounted for 31% of our revenue for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. BricoPlanit:_** We directly operate all 13 of our ‘‘Big Box’’ stores in Belgium under the BricoPlanit brand, the only pure DIY Big Box format in Belgium. Established in 2004, our BricoPlanit brand is known for its chain of DIY megastores in Belgium with a market share of approximately 15% in the Belgian DIY Market in terms of Transactional Sales for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, according to GfK. BricoPlanit offers a large range of products for home improvement projects, with approximately 49,000 SKUs stocked per store and an average floor surface area of approximately 9,000 square meters. BricoPlanit’s three largest product groups are indoor and construction products, flooring and building materials. BricoPlanit accounted for 19% of our revenue for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. Praxis:_** We directly operate 151 stores and our franchisees operate 44 stores in the Netherlands under the Praxis brand and the Praxis 1 ----- _Mega & Garden, Praxis Mega and_ _Praxis City sub-brands._ Established in 1978, Praxis is our leading DIY concept in the Netherlands, with a market share of approximately 25% of the Dutch DIY Superstores Market in terms of Transactional Sales for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, according to GfK. Praxis offers a broad product assortment that varies by store size, ranging from 8,000 to 65,000 SKUs stocked per store. The floor surface area of our Praxis stores varies from approximately 300 square meters for our _Praxis City ‘‘City’’ stores to approximately 11,900 square meters for our largeformat Praxis Mega & Garden stores. The floor surface area of our ‘‘standard’’ Praxis stores is approximately 3,000 square meters for directly operated stores and approximately 2,900 square meters for franchisee-operated stores. Praxis’s largest product groups are paint, flooring, and indoor and construction products. Praxis accounted for 50% of our revenue for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. We operate our three brands across three store formats, ‘‘City’’ stores, ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores and ‘‘Big Box’’ stores, through which we target distinct customers and project requirements. Each of our store formats offers a unique focus: City Stores:_** Our ‘‘City’’ stores, consisting of our Brico City and Praxis City sub-brands, in Belgium and the Netherlands, respectively, are located in city centers. These stores are generally small in size and focus on providing convenient access to products for routine, small-scale maintenance and repair projects, targeting both first-time and more experienced DIY consumers with basic home repair or improvement needs. Mid Box Stores:_** Our ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores consist of our Brico stores in Belgium and our Praxis stores in the Netherlands. These stores are larger in size and provide a wider range of products for larger maintenance, repair, decoration and renovation projects, targeting both first-time and more experienced DIY consumers undertaking decorative or home improvement projects that might require more resources than our ‘‘City’’ stores can provide. Big Box Stores:_** Our ‘‘Big Box’’ stores consist of our BricoPlanit stores in Belgium and our Praxis Mega and Praxis Mega & Garden stores in the Netherlands. These stores are our largest, and provide our most extensive range of products for a variety of home improvement projects, primarily targeting consumers experienced in DIY projects who are shopping for more-technical products for large DIY projects and for more-expensive decorative items. Our digital distribution channel is growing, with over 40 million online visits and e34 million in online sales, (excluding Click & Collect) or 2% of our revenue, for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. We operate our digital distribution channel through two websites, one for our Brico and BricoPlanit brands in Belgium and one for our Praxis brand in the Netherlands, in order to meet customer demand for an omnichannel shopping experience and provide greater and more convenient access to our products. In addition to traditional home delivery services, all of our store brands offer a ‘‘Click & Reserve’’ option, which allows customers to order products that do not require assembly or which the customer decides to assemble themselves online and pick up in-store, and a ‘‘Click & Collect’’ option, which allows customers to order products that require assembly and pick them up in store after they have been assembled by our specialists, each of which we believe increases the likelihood of additional or ancillary purchases by the customer. We have also opened a distribution center exclusively dedicated to our online sales. Through our Brico, BricoPlanit and Praxis digital channels, we also provide the option of Drop Shipment, whereby products are shipped directly from the supplier to the customer’s home. We 2 ----- aim to continue to develop our mobile phone and tablet applications across our store brands, enhancing the way we present our products to users and increasing the channels through which consumers can purchase them. We aim to offer our customers a strong value proposition through a comprehensive product assortment across five product categories: (i) decorating, which includes painting and lighting products, (ii) building, which includes wood, flooring and doors, (iii) tools, electrical and hardware, which includes drills and other tools and instruments, (iv) gardening, which includes garden power tools, outdoors furniture and garden wood products, and (v) installation, sanitary and kitchen, which includes plumbing products, taps and heating instruments. We aim to maximize customer choice through a multi-brand strategy that combines a wide offering of top-level branded products selectively complemented by our private label products. In the year ended February 2, 2020, we derived 74% of our Transactional Sales from third-party branded products and the remaining 26% from our private label products. For the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, we generated Transactional Sales of e1,976 million, revenue of e1,483 million, Adjusted EBITDA of e240 million, Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16) of e151 million, and had an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 16.2% and an Adjusted EBITDA margin (pre-IFRS 16) of 10.2%. Our business performed well during the COVID-19 pandemic and we benefitted from the successful implementation of the first two phases of a three-phase strategic plan that we initiated in 2016, which included initiatives such as the development of our e-commerce platform. Our revenue for the six months ended August 2, 2020, increased by e93 million, or 12%, to e861 million, from e768 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due to an increase in Like-for-Like Sales by 15.3% over the period, as a result of increased consumer focus on DIY projects due to increased time spent at home and in their gardens as a result of lockdown measures implemented in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, during which our stores in the Netherlands remained open and our stores in Belgium closed for only one month between March and April.

Subsubsection Title: Leader in a growing DIY market with a strong store network
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading DIY retailer in Belgium and the Netherlands, with strong and stable market positions underpinned by a dense network of 348 stores across multiple retail formats and brands that cater to a diverse range of DIY customers and needs. We have adapted to evolving consumer habits by opening smaller outlets in city centers and by investing in our online presence. We have an extensive footprint of 150 Brico and BricoPlanit stores in Belgium and 195 Praxis stores in the Netherlands and also operate three Brico stores in Luxembourg. According to data compiled by GfK, our Brico and BricoPlanit store brands held a combined market share of approximately 44% of the Belgian DIY Market for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. We have a particularly strong presence in selected highly populated regions such as Brussels where, according to a retail marketing agency, Brico and BricoPlanit represented an estimated 90% of market share by Transactional Sales for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. We also enjoy a strong position in the Netherlands, where we estimate that we are the second-largest DIY retailer in terms of Transactional Sales, with a total of 195 stores trading under our well-established Praxis brand and a combined market share of 25% of the Dutch DIY Superstores Market for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. We have benefitted from our online strategy and omnichannel capabilities, in particular during the COVID-19 outbreak. Our market share in Belgium and the Netherlands is supported by our long-standing presence, extensive market knowledge and strong brand visibility in these markets. We believe that the insight gained from our extensive trading history in Belgium and the Netherlands is a competitive advantage relative to new market entrants, because it positions us to identify prime retail locations and capitalize on local customer preferences.

Subsubsection Title: High degree of diversification providing resilience and stability
Subsubsection Text: We operate a diversified multi-format, multi-brand and multi-channel retail platform designed to serve the varying needs of DIY customers across Belgium and the Netherlands. Our physical network of 348 stores across Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg comprises stores with three distinct but complementary value propositions tailored to their respective geographic regions and target customers. Our ‘‘City’’ stores are designed for maximum convenience, with small surface areas in high population density locations and a specialized product range focused on immediate maintenance and repair needs. Our ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores are larger in size, with an emphasis on a superior in-store experience and an extensive range of DIY, home decoration and gardening products for small and large projects. Our 3 ----- ‘‘Big Box’’ stores are destination stores offering our widest array of products, including those required for large-scale renovations and decorative projects. The broad product offering across each of our three store formats is complemented by knowledgeable staff and expert advice tailored to the product category and specific customer need. Our complementary store formats, expert in-store advice and tailored product offerings allow us to service the full range of our customers’ DIY requirements, from one-off convenience purchases to large projects. We have also developed a ‘‘Do-It-For-Me’’ platform in Belgium and the Netherlands through which customers can find third-party professionals who can perform their DIY jobs. We allow these professionals to register on our platform and we then let customers pick the specialist they need. We aim to offer our customers a strong value proposition through a comprehensive product assortment across product categories. Our stores stock well-established brands such as Grohe, Gardena, Black & Decker, Akzo, Bosch, Knauf, Flexa and Signify. We also have distribution arrangements in place with certain key suppliers to distribute certain of their branded products exclusively in our stores and online in Belgium and the Netherlands. We seek to differentiate ourselves from competitors and to boost our range innovation by also offering our private label products as alternatives or complements to our branded offering in certain product categories such as power tools, hand tools and gardening products. With our private label products, we aim to offer equivalent quality and superior value to comparable branded products at a variety of price points through our ‘‘good,’’ ‘‘better’’ and ‘‘best’’ product ranges. The margins generated on our private label products are on average approximately 23% higher than the margins on the equivalent branded products we sell. For the year ended February 2, 2020 we generated 74% of our Transactional Sales from third-party branded products and 26% of our Transactional Sales from our private label products. This extensive and flexible product offering differentiates us from smaller competitors and allows us to optimize sales of trending DIY products.

Subsubsection Title: Dynamic business model based on a strong and flexible operating platform
Subsubsection Text: Our store portfolio consists of a mix of 65% directly operated stores and 35% franchisee-operated stores, providing operational flexibility across our different formats with the goal of maximizing our profitability in each market. We selectively open new stores in localities where we are not present and where we have identified demand for our products. Our franchise arrangements enable us to reduce the risk associated with growing our network and expanding into new localities. We seek franchise partners with the relevant expertise, specialized market knowledge and local networks required to rapidly succeed in each market, and we permit our franchisees limited flexibility to tailor a portion of their product offering to specialized local demands. However, we maintain robust, centralized control over our stores, products and messaging, thereby ensuring consistent product offerings and the uniform implementation of display and marketing initiatives across all stores. Through this combination of directly operated stores and franchisee-operated stores, we are able to efficiently leverage our well-known store brands and extend our geographic reach. We have selectively sought to convert franchisee stores to directly operated stores in selected formats during the past three years in line with our store optimization focus, and the percentage of our stores that are directly owned has increased from 53% as of April 30, 2017 to 65% as of August 2, 2020. Our brick-and-mortar stores are complemented by our two websites for the Brico and BricoPlanit brands and the Praxis brands allowing us to reach customers who may prefer to order online and who have difficulties in reaching our stores. Our extensive store network and online product offering is supplied by an efficient, diversified and flexible sourcing model that we believe, combined with the large scale of our operations, helps us to obtain favorable commercial terms with our key suppliers and preserve our margins. In recent years, we have made substantial investments in streamlining our supply chain, including the consolidation of procurement functions for Brico, BricoPlanit and Praxis in an effort to maximize synergies between our brands and leverage their combined scale in negotiations with suppliers. Our vendor management team also benefits from the A.R.E.N.A. Alliance, a procurement partnership with seven other retail groups focused on the sourcing and negotiation of supplies of DIY, garden and home improvement products. As of August 2, 2020, we sourced our products from diversified base of over 700 suppliers located primarily in Belgium, the Netherlands and Asia, compared to 900 as of April 30, 2017. We have developed our own Asian sourcing platform since 2011, which we renamed Surity. Surity negotiates and contracts directly with Asia-based suppliers through an office in Shanghai, China. We have been able to leverage knowledge of local markets through this partnership, which also improved our profitability as direct sourcing results in higher margins. In addition, we have implemented a margin enhancement program 4 ----- with the aim of building longer-term relationships with our key suppliers, reducing costs, optimizing the efficiency of our supplier base, concentrating spend and ensuring the quality and security of the supply for a number of our key products. Our procurement initiatives are supported by our SITI program, a lean inventory policy aiming to structurally decrease stock and improve working capital. We have minimized our inventory footprint, operating a single central warehouse (located between Antwerp and Brussels), which supplies our stores in both Belgium and the Netherlands with most of our products. This central warehouse is complemented by a smaller specialized warehouse in Ninove, Belgium, which supplies our stores with wood and construction products, and two ‘‘flow through’’ dock centers (one in Vianen, the Netherlands and one in Bornem, Belgium), which have helped us to efficiently manage our inventory and reduce our distribution costs. We also have a new distribution center in Roermond, the Netherlands, exclusively dedicated to the delivery of products ordered through our online sales channels, the operation of which we have contracted to a third party. We occupy approximately 100,000 square meters of warehouse space. As of August 2, 2020, approximately 24,000 SKUs are delivered through this dedicated e-commerce distribution center.

Subsubsection Title: Successful strategic initiatives have strengthened our business
Subsubsection Text: We initiated a three phase strategic improvement plan in 2016 which focused on optimizing our business, and we believe that the successful implementation of the first two phases has enabled us to grow revenue, Like-for-Like Sales and Adjusted EBITDA, has reduced operating expenses and working capital, and helped us to perform well during the COVID-19 crisis. Our ‘‘Back to Simplicity’’ strategy was initiated in 2016 with the aim of optimizing functions and reducing costs across our business, and was completed in 2018. Among other things, our ‘‘Back to Simplicity’’ strategy focused on terminating the Praxis Garden franchise format by closing our three remaining Praxis Garden stores in 2017, simplifying our administrative functions by centralizing our headquarters in Belgium and relocating our Amsterdam headquarters, reducing our fixed cost base by renegotiating rents at many of our Praxis stores and investing in our employees and their ability to increase customer satisfaction including by offering general and specialized DIY knowledge, renegotiating our collective bargaining agreement in Belgium, and reducing our electricity costs through the installation of LED lighting at our stores and offices. We initiated the second phase of our plan, our ‘‘Back to Basics’’ strategy in 2017, with the aim of enhancing our customer value proposition through the creation of a new cohesive store format across our Brico, BricoPlanit and Praxis brands, reinforcing our positioning in key product categories, enhancing efficiency of operations and customer service and building commitment from our employees through employee investment, training and empowerment. We have improved the visual identity of our stores and have sought to optimize our inventory offering by conducting a range review across all formats. We have launched a leadership path for store employees and implemented systems to train our employees to be more familiar with our products. In addition, we conducted reviews our store portfolio across all brands, resulting in the opening of 17 new stores, the relocation of four existing stores and the remodeling of six existing stores. As a result of these initiatives, we operate a profitable portfolio of stores and for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, we had only two stores with negative Adjusted EBITDA in Belgium and one store with negative Adjusted EBITDA in the Netherlands. Other stores that had been loss making in prior periods have either been converted to newly-opened City stores in the Netherlands or closed or sold to franchisees in Belgium. We have also identified specific initiatives for the remaining stores with negative Adjusted EBITDA, such as rent renegotiation, active marketing campaign or store closure. We also successfully phased out our Formido brand in the Netherlands. We converted 40 of our Formido stores into Praxis stores, refurbishing these stores and the products they offer to reflect the Praxis brand image, sold 23 stores, and closed the remaining 11 Formido stores. This initiative strengthened our Praxis brand, and we have maintained our market share in the Netherlands through the conversion process. All of our stores in the Netherlands are now operated under the Praxis brand. After conversion to the Praxis brand, the 30 best-performing converted Formido stores has experienced an average gross margin increase of 25% per store for the year ended February 3, 2019, compared to the year ended January 31, 2018, with the five best-performing converted Formido stores experiencing increases in gross margins of 50% on average. 5 ----- We also successfully completed our e-commerce optimization as part of our ‘‘Back to Basics’’ strategy, and have become the leading DIY omnichannel retailer in Benelux, with a variety of sales and delivery channels and the development of our two new, more flexible and mobile-friendly, websites designed to maximize the accessibility of our products. We have invested in the features and functionality of our branded online channels in an effort to diversify our revenue streams and capture a greater share of the growing DIY e-commerce market in Belgium and the Netherlands. For example, we combined the two websites for our Brico and BricoPlanit brands in Belgium, and we now have one website for our Brico and BricoPlanit brands for the Belgian market and one website for our Praxis brand for the Dutch market. These websites offer online ordering capabilities and detailed information on our products. We have also opened a distribution center exclusively dedicated to the delivery of products ordered through our online sales channels in order to improve the speed and efficiency of our delivery of online orders. The expansion of our digital platform and the integration of online capabilities into our physical stores, such as in-store tablets and Wi-Fi access points in all our stores for the ordering of products unavailable in stores, has also had a positive impact on our profitability, as it is less costly to fulfill orders that are picked up in our stores through our Click & Collect and Click & Reserve services than orders that are delivered directly to our customers. We also focus on community interaction, and distribute inspirational DIY videos explaining DIY techniques to our customers and potential customers in order to increase brand loyalty and showcase products available in our stores. We have also increased our social media coverage to enable interaction with customers and improve after sale communications.

Subsubsection Title: Resilience demonstrated through the COVID-19 outbreak
Subsubsection Text: Our business performed well during the COVID-19 outbreak, in part due to consumer focus on DIY projects while in lockdown or working from home. Even though governments in Belgium and the Netherlands implemented measures to contain the spread of the virus and these measures affected our business operations, along with those of other retailers in the markets in which we operate, the growth of Belgian and Dutch DIY markets significantly accelerated since the beginning of 2020. This was partly due to the COVID-19 outbreak, which resulted in strong customer focus on home improvements and DIY projects, especially small home repairs. This trend accelerated when governments eased lockdown measures in June 2020, with customers in Belgium resuming DIY projects that they were unable to 6 ----- complete due to the closure of stores in Belgium, as illustrated in the following graphs (according to GfK): 10SEP202018085811 While we initially experienced a substantial decrease in sales in Belgium due to store closures, our stores subsequently experienced sales growth in late April, May and June, and sales in those months were higher than for the comparative months in 2019, primarily due to increased DIY activity as a result of our customers spending more time at home and in their gardens. Our stores in the Netherlands remained open throughout the pandemic, with limited opening hours, and performed well, and our sales in the Netherlands for the period from March to June were higher than for the comparable period in 2019, as customers increasingly focused on DIY home improvements, which we presume resulted from increased time spent at home as well as adapting the home space for additional functions including school and work. We incurred e9 million in costs incurred for additional health and safety measures in our stores during the six months ended August 2, 2020. We believe that the improvements implemented as part of our strategic initiatives, allowed us to take advantage of this trend and contributed to our business’ strong performance during the COVID-19 outbreak. For example, most of the Formido stores that we converted to Praxis are small stores that consumers favored during the pandemic outbreak, which confirmed our strategy to focus on a diversified multi-format platform. We also benefitted from our e-commerce optimization strategy over the last three years and the investments in our product range availability, as online shopping and delivery increased during the outbreak. Our online sales (excluding Click & Collect) in Belgium increased by 350% for the six months ended August, 2, 2020, compared to the same period in 2019, and online sales (excluding Click & Collect) also significantly increased in the Netherlands, with an increase of 23% for the six months ended August, 2, 2020, compared to the same period in 2019. We believe that the COVID-19 outbreak and subsequent government measures have contributed to an increased consumer focus on home and garden improvements, and we believe this will be a long-term trend with a positive impact our operations. 7 10SEP202018085811 -----

Subsubsection Title: Improved operating performance leading to deleveraging
Subsubsection Text: As a result of the strength of our business and the success of our strategic initiatives, since 2017 our business has steadily grown, our margins have improved and we have maintained strong cash conversion. From the year ended January 31, 2018 to the year ended February 2, 2020, our revenues grew at a CAGR of 1% and we maintained strong growth in profitability, with Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16) growing at a CAGR of 9% during that period. For the years ended January 31, 2018, February 3, 2019 and February 2, 2020 and the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, our Gross Profit Margins were 34.5%, 34.8%, 36.0% and 36.7%, respectively, and our Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16) margins were 6.9%, 8.2%, 8.0% and 10.2%, respectively. We have demonstrated that the investments in our various initiatives to revamp our business have delivered strong cash flow generation, even through the COVID-19 outbreak. Cash Flow Conversion for the years ended January 31, 2018, February 3, 2019 and February 2, 2020, and for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020 was 128%, 124%, 112% and 108%, respectively. We focus on actively managing our working capital to further improve our cash generation, and since 2018 our inventory optimization program has positively impacted our change in operating working capital. For instance, for the six months ended August 2, 2020, our change in adjusted net working capital amounted to e138 million. Our level of maintenance capital expenditure (which includes store refurbishments and product range reviews) was stable at e24 million, e27 million and e27 million for the years ended February 2, 2020, February 3, 2019 and January 31, 2018, respectively, and could be reduced slightly if necessary in the event of a decrease in Adjusted EBITDA. Our financial resilience, in the face of a challenging economic environment following the outbreak of COVID-19, has been due in part to the innovative, cost-saving initiatives implemented by our leadership team, which have strengthened our fundamentals and streamlined our business.

Subsubsection Title: Strong management team committed to sustainable development
Subsubsection Text: We have a highly experienced and professional senior management team headed by Guy Colleau, our Chief Executive Officer, who benefits from more than 30 years of international consumer and retail experience. Our Chief Financial Officer, Luc Leunis, has held executive positions in our group for almost 20 years and benefits from 25 years of retail experience. Our management team has significant experience in the retail and DIY industries, a deep understanding of the Belgian and Dutch markets and an excellent track record of executing strategic objectives. Through a comprehensive review of our leadership position in the Belgian and Dutch DIY markets, our customer value propositions and the management of our operations, our senior management team also successfully implemented our ‘‘Back to Simplicity,’’ ‘‘Back to Basics’’ and ‘‘Make-it-Easy’’ strategic plans, which have remodeled our business and increased our profitability. Our management team believes that sustainable development with positive impact on the environment and on society will prove rewarding on the long-term, and we aspire to do business as a responsible corporate citizen. We are committed to a sound governance structure and operate a supervisory board that consists of both investors and external directors. We seek to respect people and the planet and uphold values and ethical standards. We offer our customers the possibility of delivering old batteries, tools, bulbs and electrical waste that we subsequently dispose of in a sustainable manner and continuously seek to improve the sustainability of our sourcing and reduce our carbon footprint. Our management team has implemented initiatives throughout our business operations to increase their sustainability, such as increased use of sustainable products and reduced use of disposable packaging.

Subsubsection Title: Continuing to improve our operating performance through effective cost management and working capital optimization
Subsubsection Text: We plan to continue to reduce costs and optimize our use of working capital in order to maintain and enhance our cost position and improve our operating performance and profitability, in line with the ‘‘Back to Simplicity’’ and ‘‘Back to Basics’’ phases of our strategic improvement plan. Our ‘‘Make-it-Easy’’ strategy also aims to, among other things, further improve our cost savings and optimize 8 ----- our use of working capital. Cost-saving initiatives include the installation of self-scanning desks for self-checkout at our stores, synergies in our Brico and BricoPlanit marketing costs, increasing the sourcing of our private-label products and reduced storage times between the offloading of incoming supplies and their onwards reshipment. We continuously seek to improve our cost base which in turn allows us to offer compelling pricing to our customers, including through partnerships such as the A.R.E.N.A. Alliance to negotiate better terms with suppliers. We also intend to reduce the cost of our utilities and reevaluate certain of our maintenance and repair contracts. We also aim to improve our working capital requirements. Our working capital optimization initiatives include further strengthening relationships with certain preferred suppliers and the rollout of our SITI program, which will enhance our inventory management by, for example, allowing us to return to certain relationship suppliers of certain products that we have not sold at the end of a promotion campaign. We also encourage members of certain teams and committees to meet specific cost reduction and productivity improvement targets each year, with a material amount of their compensation tied to their performance against these targets. We require that capital projects meet certain return thresholds, which encourages prudent levels of spending on expansion and cost-saving opportunities.

Subsubsection Title: Reinforce our positioning in each of our product categories with a comprehensive product offering at compelling prices
Subsubsection Text: We aim to further strengthen our position by continuing to perform full reviews and optimizations of our product range to better tailor our offering to customer demands. We perform these reviews periodically for each product category to identify, stock and market products which we believe have high growth potential or reflect consumer trends. We then prioritize the visibility of these product categories in our stores and on our website. For example, we aim to increase our standing as a specialist in certain key product categories, such as ‘‘non-mobile’’ products and tools for larger home improvement and installation projects, by showcasing these products in our stores more often. We also intend to further increase the product density in our ‘‘City’’ stores by reducing the width of store aisles to increase SKUs carried and showcase more of our product offering. In our ‘‘Mid Box’’ and ‘‘City’’ stores, in which due to store size our product range is necessarily more limited compared to our ‘‘Big Box’’ stores, we have scaled our product range more appropriately to customer demand, offering a strategic selection of SKUs per product category in order to efficiently service customer demand while managing our inventory levels. Furthermore, we have used and intend to continue to use a range of targeted promotions to highlight our capabilities as a multi-specialist retailer and comprehensive DIY solutions provider. Our upcoming promotion initiatives include sale days on which we provide certain discounts across all product categories, as well as promotional events targeting specific seasonal or product categories, particularly in our ‘‘Big Box’’ stores. For instance, ‘‘wood month’’ will promote our capabilities as a wood products specialist, and ‘‘gardening days’’ will showcase for customers our comprehensive and compelling range of outdoor products.

Subsubsection Title: Enhancing our operational efficiency and customer service by leveraging our digital platform
Subsubsection Text: As part of our ‘‘Make-it-Easy’’ strategy, we intend to (i) leverage our e-commerce activities to move into markets where we are currently not present by expanding the reach of our websites internationally to commercialize our private label and exclusive brands in these markets, such as in France, (ii) invest in high quality content to increase search engine optimization and search engine advertising, (iii) continue to increase the amount of SKUs available on our online stores, (iv) launch a product locator app, and (v) increase the amount of orders that can be fulfilled through either Drop Shipment or through our dedicated e-commerce distribution platform. All our product ranges are available on our digital platform and we have further expanded the availability of SKUs on our websites through the development of our Drop Shipment Model, through which certain suppliers deliver products directly to the consumer’s home. We are working on making all SKUs that are available in-store available online, and are also expanding our catalogue of online products to include product categories that are not available in-store. As a result, the number of SKUs on each of our store brand websites may grow to substantially exceed the number of SKUs in the corresponding brand’s physical stores. The number of SKUs available on our online stores grew from approximately 35,000 as of January 31, 2018, to approximately 60,000 as of August 2, 2020. We view our digital platform as an extension of our stores. We believe that our opportunities to expand our 9 ----- e-commerce sales are greater in areas where we have brick-and-mortar stores, as e-commerce sales are positively impacted by the convenience of our Click & Collect option. We believe that expanding the number of SKUs available on our store brand websites will be an important competitive advantage because this will increase the accessibility of our product offering and further develop our strategic growth initiatives for our multi-channel platform.

Subsubsection Title: Improving Like-for-Like Sales through employee investment, training and empowerment
Subsubsection Text: Our team members drive our success. As part of our ‘‘Back to Basics’’ strategy, we built commitment through employee investment, training and empowerment including through the launch of a leadership program for store employees and of a training academy for administrative employees, the implementation of an e-learning platform for our employees and the establishment of a new digital human resources management platform. As part of our strategic growth initiatives under our ‘‘Make-it-Easy’’ strategy, we will continue to invest in our workforce and partners with training and individual empowerment, including through (i) the rolling out of a company-wide onboarding program, (ii) the simplification of internal tools such as a digital platform to manage human-resources matters and an internal social network, (iii) increased role-diversification and (iv) the rewarding of internal talents. In addition, we believe that our customers place significant value on technical knowledge and service, and that one of our key advantages is our ability to provide expert advice to our customers across all product categories. Due to our wide range of products, and the highly technical nature of many DIY products, customers increasingly rely on well-trained sales associates to offer knowledgeable assistance in product selection and use. To serve this need, our employees participate in continuous training through our ‘‘Maxeda Academy’’ program, including formal workshops, seminars and certification programs to build technical, managerial and customer service skills. We are also investing in our information technology to introduce online training courses on DIY knowledge for our employees, and we are working with our product suppliers to increase the amount of hands-on training provided to our employees with respect to new products. In addition, we have customer service measurement systems and recognition programs in place for management, sales associates and other employees to measure and encourage overall customer satisfaction. By having more knowledgeable employees, we believe we can offer better customer service and, accordingly, increase our sales.

Subsubsection Title: Refining our three store formats and brands to enhance customer value propositions and accessibility
Subsubsection Text: We seek to continuously improve the customer experience in our stores by adapting to the changing preferences of our target customers and their project requirements. We intend to continue to refurbish stores on a rolling basis to increase revenue and attract new customers through spatial optimization and user-friendly new store layouts. For instance, to strengthen the Praxis brand, we are seeking to improve the customer value propositions by adjusting prices of our products and product ranges at our Praxis City ‘‘City’’ stores and standard Praxis ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores to attract more customers into these stores, which we believe will result in increased sales density and improved profitability, bringing Praxis’s profitability in line with our Brico stores. As of August 2, 2020, we opened 15 stores that apply the new Praxis format, of which four are in Belgium and eleven are in the Netherlands, and refurbished 18 of our stores to reflect this new format, of which nine are in Belgium and nine are in the Netherlands. Furthermore, we plan to continue opening new stores in areas where we do not currently operate. Our ‘‘Make-it-Easy’’ strategy includes certain initiatives through which we intend to continue to refine our store formats to enhance customer value and increase accessibility. Such initiatives include the expansion of our BricoPlanit network to approximately 20 stores from 13 stores. We seek to improve our market-leading positions in Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands by selectively expanding into new local regions and opening additional directly operated stores and franchisee-operated stores that meet our rigorous selection criteria and that will allow us to cover areas that we do not currently serve through brick-and-mortar stores. Furthermore, we aim to increase the accessibility of our stores through selective strategic relocations and facility improvements tailored to the needs of our customers and trends in our markets. For example, we intend to relocate certain stores to better retail locations along highly traveled roads benefiting from higher footfall or visibility. We also anticipate that we will extend the Sunday trading hours at certain of our Belgian stores, to the extent permitted by law, because we believe the weekend allows our customers the greatest opportunity to visit our stores and make 10 ----- in-person purchases. We continue to assess new franchisee-operated stores on a case-by-case basis and monitor our store base to selectively close stores that do not meet our expectations.

Based on our key strengths, our strategic plan currently focuses on growth in revenue and profitability, including through the third phase of our strategic improvement plan, our ‘‘Make-it-Easy’’ strategy, which we launched in 2019 and expect to complete by 2023.

On the Issue Date, the Issuer will issue the Notes offered hereby and use the proceeds of the Offering together with cash on hand at the Issuer to: - fund the Existing Notes Redemption; and - pay fees and expenses incurred in connection therewith. The estimated sources and uses of the proceeds from the Offering are set forth in ‘‘Use of _Proceeds.’’_ During the six months ended August 2, 2020, we repurchased e40 million in principal amount of Existing Notes. These Existing Notes are currently held by us and we intend to cancel these Existing Notes prior to completion of the Offering, such that there will no longer be any Existing Notes outstanding upon completion of the Existing Notes Redemption. The Offering, the application of the proceeds from the Offering, together with the entry by the Issuer and certain of its subsidiaries into the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement are collectively referred to in this offering memorandum as the ‘‘Refinancing.’’ See also ‘‘Description of Other Indebtedness— _Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.’’_

Ardian is a world-leading private investment house with assets of $100 billion managed or advised in Europe, the Americas and Asia. The company is majority-owned by its employees. It keeps entrepreneurship at its heart and focuses on delivering excellent investment performance to its global investor base. Through its commitment to shared outcomes for all stakeholders, Ardian’s activities fuel individual, corporate and economic growth around the world. Holding close its core values of excellence, loyalty and entrepreneurship, Ardian maintains a truly global network, with more than 690 employees working from fifteen offices across Europe (Frankfurt, Jersey, London, Luxembourg, Madrid, Milan, Paris and Zurich), the Americas (New York, San Francisco and Santiago) and Asia (Beijing, Singapore, Tokyo and Seoul). It manages funds on behalf of around 1,000 clients through five pillars of investment expertise: Fund of Funds, Direct Funds, Infrastructure, Real Estate and Private Debt.

GoldenTree Asset Management is a global asset management firm that specializes in opportunities across the credit universe in sectors such as high yield bonds, leveraged loans, distressed debt structured products, emerging markets, private equity and credit-themed equities. The firm was founded in 2000 with offices in New York, London, Singapore, Sydney, Tokyo and Dublin, and manages over $35 billion in assets under management as of August 1, 2020.

As of the date of this offering memorandum, Ardian and GoldenTree Asset Management, the two largest shareholders of Maxeda DIY Group, indirectly owned 38.2% and 25.5%, respectively, of the class A ordinary shares of Maxeda DIY Group, which constitute the only class of voting securities of our group. See ‘‘Principal Shareholders.’’

Based on management accounts of Maxeda DIY Group, we estimate that for the one month ended September 4, 2020 compared to the one month ended September 6, 2019, our revenue increased by approximately 23%, from approximately e102 million for the one month ended September 6, 2019, to approximately e125 million for the one month ended September 4, 2020. Our revenue in Belgium and Luxembourg increased by approximately 25%, from approximately e55 million for the one month ended September 6, 2019, to approximately e68 million for the one month ended September 4, 2020 and our 11 ----- revenue in the Netherlands increased by approximately 21%, from approximately e47 million for the one month ended September 6, 2019, to approximately e57 million for the one month ended September 4, 2020. As of September 4, 2020, we estimate that we had cash and cash equivalents of e183 million, which includes e11 million of social charges in Belgium for March, April, May and June 2020, which we intend to pay in December 2020. _The preliminary results and estimates presented above have not been audited, are derived from internal management accounts, are the responsibility of management of Maxeda DIY Group and are subject to our financial closing procedures. These procedures have not been completed. While we believe these preliminary results and estimates to be reasonable, our actual results could vary from these estimates and these differences could be material. As such, you should not place undue reliance on this information. This information may not be indicative of our performance in the remainder of the financial quarter, the financial year or any future period. See ‘‘Forward-looking Statements,’’ ‘‘Risk Factors’’ and ‘‘Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations’’ in this offering memorandum for a more complete discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our future performance._ 12 -----

(“Maxeda DIY”) Non Guarantor Guarantor Subsidiaries[(4)] Subsidiaries[(4)] Guarantors Issuer Restricted Group 10SEP202018085951 (1) As of the date of this offering memorandum, Ardian and GoldenTree Asset Management, the two largest shareholders of Maxeda DIY Group, indirectly owned 38.2% and 25.5%, respectively, of the class A ordinary shares of Maxeda DIY Group, which constitute the only class of voting securities of Maxeda DIY Group. See ‘‘Principal Shareholders.’’ 13 ----- (2) The Notes will be general senior secured obligations of the Issuer and will be guaranteed by the Guarantors on the Issue Date. On or about the Issue Date, the Notes and Guarantees will be secured by the Collateral. See ‘‘Description of the _Notes—Security’’. Pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement, the Collateral will also secure the Revolving Credit Facility and in_ the future may also secure hedging obligations and other indebtedness permitted to be incurred under the Indenture and secured on an equal basis with the Notes. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, in the event of enforcement of the security interests over the Collateral, holders of Notes will receive proceeds from the Collateral only after the Revolving Credit Facility, certain hedging obligations and certain indebtedness permitted to be incurred on a priority basis under the Indenture have been repaid in full. See ‘‘Description of Other Indebtedness—Intercreditor Agreement’’. (3) The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will provide for drawings of up to e65 million under the Revolving Credit Facility. Subject to certain limitations, certain subsidiaries of the Issuer, including the Guarantors, which will also guarantee the Revolving Credit Facility, will be borrowers under the Revolving Credit Facility. The same subsidiaries that initially guarantee the Notes also guarantee the Revolving Credit Facility and the same Collateral that will initially secure Notes also secures the Revolving Credit Facility. See ‘‘Description of Other Indebtedness—Revolving Credit Facility Agreement’’ for further information. (4) As of the Issue Date, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Notes will be guaranteed by the Guarantors. The Guarantees are subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement. The obligations of a Guarantor under its Guarantee will also be limited as necessary to prevent the relevant Guarantee from constituting a fraudulent conveyance or unlawful financial assistance under applicable law, or otherwise reflect limitations under applicable law. By virtue of these limitations, a Guarantor’s obligation under its Guarantee could be significantly less than amounts payable with respect to the Notes, or a Guarantor may have effectively no obligation under its Guarantee. Other indebtedness of the Guarantors may not be similarly limited. See ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks related to the Notes—Each Guarantee and security may be subject to certain limitations on _enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit its validity and enforceability.’’ The validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to the_ limitations described in ‘‘Certain Insolvency Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the _Guarantees and the Security Interests.’’ For the six months ended August 2, 2020, the Guarantors generated 95% and 93%_ of our consolidated revenue and Adjusted EBITDA, respectively, and as of August 2, 2020, the Guarantors held 76% of our consolidated total assets. As of August 2, 2020, our subsidiaries that will not guarantee the Notes did not have any outstanding third-party financial indebtedness other than lease liabilities. 14 -----

Reasons . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** In the event of certain developments affecting taxation which cause the Issuer to pay additional amounts, the Issuer may redeem the relevant Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption. See ‘‘Description of the Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.’’ Change of Control . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Upon the occurrence of certain events defined as constituting a change of control, the Issuer may be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest to the date of purchase. A change of control will not be deemed to have occurred on one occasion if, pro forma for such change of control, a specified consolidated total net leverage ratio calculated in accordance with the 18 ----- ‘‘Description of the Notes’’ is not exceeded as a result of such event. See ‘‘Description of the Notes—Change of Control.’’ Certain Covenants . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture, among other things, will restrict the ability of the Issuer and the restricted subsidiaries of the Issuer to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - create or incur certain liens; - make certain payments, including dividends or other distributions, with respect to the shares of the Issuer; - prepay or redeem subordinated debt or equity; - make certain investments; - create encumbrances or restrictions on the payment of dividends or other distributions, loans or advances to and on the transfer of assets to the Issuer or its restricted subsidiaries; - sell, lease or transfer certain assets including stock of restricted subsidiaries; - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; - consolidate or merge with other entities; - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes; and - amend certain documents. Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See ‘‘Description of the Notes—Certain _Covenants.’’_ Transfer Restrictions . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction and are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See ‘‘Transfer Restrictions.’’ We have not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to, register the Notes (including by way of an exchange offer) with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. No Prior Market . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no established trading market. Although the Initial Purchasers have advised us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market making at any time without notice. Accordingly, there can be no assurance that an active trading market will develop for the Notes. Listing . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange. There can be no assurance, however, that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained.
