Subsubsection Text: Belgium and Luxembourg . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 35.8% 37.0% — Netherlands . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 33.6% 35.6% — _Revenue_ Revenue for the six months ended August 2, 2020, increased by e93 million, or 12%, to e861 million, from e768 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due to an increase in Like-for-Like Sales by 15.3% over the period as a result of increased time spent at home by consumers due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to increased focus on DIY projects. Our stores in the Netherlands did not close during the COVID-19 pandemic and our stores in Belgium were only closed for part of March and April 2020. Revenue for Belgium and Luxembourg for the six months ended August 2, 2020, increased by e8 million, or 2%, to e416 million, from e408 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due to a 5.3% increase in Like-for-Like Sales in Belgium and Luxembourg over the period, driven by higher sales in late April, May and June 2020 compared to the corresponding period in 2019. This was primarily due to increased DIY activity as a result of our customers spending more time at home and in their gardens. Revenue for the Netherlands for the six months ended August 2, 2020, increased by e84 million, or 23%, to e444 million, from e360 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due an increase in Like-for-Like Sales in the Netherlands by 27% over the period driven by increased consumer focus on DIY projects as a result of time spent at home due to the COVID-19 pandemic. 74 ----- _Cost of sales_ Cost of sales for the six months ended August 2, 2020 increased by e49 million, or 10%, to e548 million, from e499 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due to the increase in sales over the period. _Gross profit_ Gross profit for the six months ended August 2, 2020 increased by e44 million, or 16%, to e313 million, from e269 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due to an increase in net sales compared to the previous period and an increase in Gross Profit Margin. Gross Profit Margin for the six months ended August 2, 2020, increased to 36.3%, from 35.0% for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due to the reduction in footfall-oriented promotional events due to social distancing measures during the six months ended August 2, 2020, compared to the previous period and a higher margin for goods sold at full price. Gross Profit Margin for Belgium and Luxembourg for the six months ended August 2, 2020, increased to 37%, from 35.8% for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due to lower discounts and a higher margin for goods sold at full price. Gross Profit Margin for the Netherlands for the six months ended August 2, 2020, increased to 35.6%, from 33.6% for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due to lower discounts and a higher margin for goods sold at full price. _Selling and distribution costs_ Selling and distribution costs for the six months ended August 2, 2020, decreased by e5 million, or 3%, to e191 million, from e196 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due to lower operating costs of e7 million as a result of the temporary closure of certain of our stores in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, and a decrease in depreciation of right-of-use assets of e7 million, partially offset by increased operating costs incurred in connection with our e-commerce platform due to increased volumes of products sold online and e9 million of costs incurred in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic, including additional safety and security costs, cleaning costs and labor costs, including e1 million in rent concessions from landlords. _General and administrative expenses_ General and administrative expenses for the six months ended August 2, 2020 decreased by e4 million, or 11%, to e31 million, from e35 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due to higher administrative and general expenses incurred in the six months ended August 4, 2019, attributable to the conversion of certain Formido stores into Praxis stores. _Financial income_ Financial income for the six months ended August 2, 2020, increased by e1 million, or 100%, to e2 million, from e1 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due to increased income from subleases. _Financial expense_ Financial expense for the six months ended August 2, 2020, increased by e1 million, or 4%, to e29 million, from e28 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due to a e1 million reevaluation of outstanding foreign currency contracts. _Income taxes_ Income taxes for the six months ended August 2, 2020, increased by e3 million, or 150%, to e5 million, from e2 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due an increase in income before taxes partly offset by a decrease in effective tax rate from 24% for the six months ended August 4, 2019 to 7% for the six months ended August 2, 2020. 75 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The table below sets forth certain information related to our cash flows:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our primary source of liquidity is cash flow from operations. Our cash needs relate primarily to capital and other expenditures for opening new stores, maintaining and refurbishing existing stores, meeting debt service requirements and funding our working capital requirements. The components of our working capital are inventory, trade and other receivables, trade and other payables, excluding short-term loans from credit institutions, and provisions. We believe that, based on our current cash flows, these sources of liquidity, together with existing available borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility, will be sufficient to fund our operations, capital expenditure and debt service for at least the next twelve months. We are highly leveraged and have significant debt service obligations. As of the Issue Date, after giving effect to the Refinancing, we expect to have e889 million of indebtedness, comprising primarily of the Notes and lease liabilities. We will also be able to borrow up to e65 million under the Revolving Credit Facility. The availability of the Revolving Credit Facility is dependent upon certain conditions described further under ‘‘Description of Other Indebtedness—Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.’’ The Indenture governing the Notes offered hereby will contain, and the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains, restrictive covenants that may limit our ability to finance our future opportunities and capital needs, or pursue business opportunities and activities. In addition, the Revolving Credit Facility also requires us to comply with a leverage ratio, under certain circumstances, in order for us to continue to be able to draw funds under this facility. We may from time to time seek to retire or repurchase our outstanding debt through cash purchases, in open market purchases, privately negotiated transactions or otherwise. Such repurchases, if any, will depend on market conditions, our liquidity requirements, contractual restrictions and other factors. Our ability to generate cash depends on our future operating performance, which in turn depends to some extent on general economic, financial, industry and other factors, many of which are beyond our control, such as the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as the other factors discussed in ‘‘—Key _factors affecting results of operations’’ and ‘‘Risk Factors.’’ Trade credit from our suppliers is also an_ important source of financing for the purchase of the inventory we sell in our stores. Accordingly, the loss of, or reduction in, trade credit can have a significant adverse impact on our inventory levels and operating cash flow and can negatively impact our liquidity. Our suppliers may seek credit insurance to protect against nonpayment of amounts due to them. If credit insurance is not available to suppliers at reasonable terms or at all, suppliers may demand accelerated payment of amounts due to them or require advance payments or letters of credit before goods are shipped to us. Furthermore, a negative change in our credit ratings or our suppliers’ perception of our creditworthiness may impact their willingness to provide trade credit to us and adversely affect our cash flow. 79 ----- We cannot guarantee that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations or that future debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Cash flow from operating activities_ Our cash flow from operating activities is primarily driven by movements in our operating results before amortization, depreciation and impairment, our net working capital, and interest and tax expenses. Our cash flow from operating activities for the six months ended August 2, 2020 amounted to an inflow of e248 million, primarily due to operating results of e91 million and an increase in cash flow from working capital of e139 million, primarily attributable to an increase in cash flow from trade and other payables of e167 million primarily due to higher trade creditors due to increased buying volumes as a result of increased sales volumes, an increase in other taxes and social security contributions of e40 million of which e24 million were deferred to the third and fourth financial quarters, and an increase in cash flow from inventories of e3 million due to the implementation of our SITI program partially offset by a decrease in cash flow from trade and other receivables of e31 million due to additional supplier benefits or rebates due to an increase in sales volumes partly offset by lower outstanding franchisee debtors due to improved management. Operating results were higher compared to the previous period in part because of a higher revenue and an increase in Gross Profit Margin. Our cash flow from operating activities for the six months ended August 4, 2019 amounted to an inflow of e50 million, primarily due to operating results of e38 million, which were partly offset by a cash outflow from the movements in working capital of e8 million, interest expenses of e27 million and a corporate income tax liability paid of e10 million. Our cash outflow from the movements in working capital was primarily due to higher inventories of e8 million due to an increased number of directlyowned stores, and the phasing out of supplier rebates of e19 million which was offset by a cash inflow of trade and other payables of e19 million due to higher stock intake and phasing. Depreciation has remained stable at e18 million. Our cash flow from operating activities for the year ended February 2, 2020, amounted to an inflow of e112 million, primarily due to operating results of e56 million, depreciation of e38 million, depreciation of right-of-use assets of e78 million as a result of the application of IFRS 16 and a cash inflow from movements in working capital of e16 million, partly offset by interest expenses of e58 million and a corporate income tax liability paid of e10 million. Our cash inflow from movements in working capital was mainly due to an inventory decrease of e7 million as a result of an inventory reduction program implemented to address high inventory levels and due to a decrease in trade and other receivables of e10 million due to stricter receivables management and the phasing of supplier rebates. The increase in interest expenses over the period was primarily due to the impact of IFRS 16 (e23 million). Our cash flow from operating activities for the year ended February 3, 2019, amounted to an inflow of e49 million, primarily due to operating results of e57 million and a cash inflow from the movements in working capital of e7 million, partly offset by interest expenses of e32 million and a corporate income tax liability paid of e10 million. Cash flow from the movements in working capital was mainly due to an increase in outstanding trade payables of e14 million at the end of the year as we had to replenish our 80 ----- weather related stock as a result of a successful season in 2018, offset by franchise receivables collection and phasing of supplier rebates of e15 million, which resulted in an increase in trade and other receivables. This inflow was partly offset by an increase in inventory of e22 million as a result of the Formido conversion, which resulted in inventory purchases and new floor plan, increased product density and the acquisition of other franchisee-operated stores such as Benimmo. Our cash inflow from operating activities was also lower due to a e8 million decrease in cash set aside for provisions, mainly related to good receivables management, the takeover of franchisee-operated stores and the settlement of claims. In addition, our depreciation and amortization has increased to e36 million as a result of investments in information and communication technologies and the acquisitions of Formido and Benimmo franchisee-operated stores. Our cash flow from operating activities for the year ended January 31, 2018, amounted to an inflow of e22 million, primarily due to operating results of e54 million, which were partly offset by negative cash flow from the movements in working capital of e11 million, interest expenses of e43 million and a corporate income tax liability paid of e8 million. Cash flow from the movement in inventory was stable and primarily related to purchases of inventory due to the increased product density in our stores and the addition of directly operated stores over the period, fully offset by an overall decrease of our inventory. Cash flow from the movement in trade and other payables for the year ended January 31, 2018, decreased by e8 million compared to the year ended January 31, 2017, mainly due to lower accruals (restructuring costs as at January 31, 2017), other taxes and social security contribution (early payment as at January 31, 2018) and lower payables due to lower stock intake. _Cash flow used in investing activities_ Cash used in investing activities principally relates to investments on growth in our trading space, the refurbishment and maintenance of our existing stores, concept changes, range review- related changes and the investment in our multi-channel platforms, our distribution center and IT as well as intangible assets. These Existing Notes are currently held by us and we intend to cancel these Existing Notes prior to completion of the Offering, such that there will no longer be any Existing Notes outstanding upon completion of the Existing Notes Redemption. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted net working capital consists of inventories, trade and other receivables, trade and other payables (excluding short-term loans from credit institutions) and provisions, adjusted to eliminate parent intercompany payables. Our most important trading period in terms of revenue, operating results and cash flow has historically been the spring and early summer, with 41% of our revenue in the year ended February 2, 2020 generated from April 1, 2019 to August 4, 2019, when we experience a significant increase in sales of outdoor and gardening products, among other things. During this season our revenue tends to outpace our creditor payments, resulting in negative working capital towards the end of the summer season. We require liquidity in order to fund such higher working capital needs, and we fund such liquidity from cash and/or drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility. For instance, for the six months ended August 2, 2020, our change in adjusted net working capital amounted to e138 million, primarily due to an increase in trade and other payables of e167 million and a decrease in inventories of e3 million which are partly offset by an increase in trade and other receivables of e31 million and a decrease in provisions of e1 million. In addition, we experience significant fluctuations in our intra-month working capital due to regularly scheduled payments on certain days of each month to our trade creditors as well as our employees and landlords. We expect to continue benefitting from our working capital initiatives, including out SITI program and store relocations and closures going forward 82 ----- The following table sets forth our change in adjusted net working capital for the periods indicated.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In Belgium, we contribute to a defined benefit plan for executives. The plan is final-pay based and is administered by an insurance company. During the six months ended August 2, 2020 and August 4, 2019 and the years ended February 2, 2020, February 3, 2019 and January 31, 2018, we contributed e2 million, e2 million, e4 million, e5 million and e4 million, respectively, to our defined benefit plan. The vast majority of our Dutch employees who are older than 20 years participate in a multiemployer pension plan. In the Netherlands, we also have a number of plans for jubilee benefits. During each of the six months ended August 2, 2020 and August 4, 2019 and the years ended February 2, 2020, February 3, 2019 and January 31, 2018, we made provisions of e4 million for such plans. Our employee benefit plans expose us to actuarial risks such as longevity risk, interest rate risk, salary risk and investment risk. Longevity risk relates to the mortality assumptions used to value the defined benefit obligation where an increase in participants’ life expectancies will increase a plan’s liability. Interest rate risk relates to the discount rate used to value the defined benefit obligation where a decrease in the discount rate will increase a plan’s liability, which, however, will be partially offset by an increase in the return on a plan’s investments in debt instruments. Salary risk relates to salary increase assumptions used to value the defined benefit obligation, where an increase will result in a higher plan liability.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We manage our net exposure to interest rate risk through a combination of fixed rate and variable rate financial debt. To manage this mix, Maxeda DIY Group may enter into interest rate swap agreements, in which we have exchanged periodic payments based on a notional amount and agreed upon fixed and variable interest rates, and forward contracts, in which we exchange fixed amounts of foreign currency and fixed amounts of euro. We are exposed to market risks, and will continue to be so exposed after completion of the Refinancing, primarily as a result of changes in interest rates, particularly in relation to borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility. Financial liabilities issued at floating rates will expose us to cash flow interest rate risk, while financial liabilities issued at fixed rates expose us to fair value interest rate risk. To manage our exposure to changes in interest rates we expect to continue to use interest rate swaps.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to foreign exchange risk, primarily with respect to the U.S. dollar. However, this risk is limited because the vast majority of our activities is denominated in euro. Our principal foreign currency exposure arises from the purchase of overseas-sourced products through a sourcing agent in Asia. Our policy is to hedge against the commitments recorded in our ordering system. We estimate that 11% of our purchased goods for the year ended February 2, 2020, were sourced from Asia. The currency risk on currently outstanding purchasing orders is hedged by using financial derivatives. These derivatives are recognized in our statement of financial position.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk arises mostly in connection with cash flows generated by and used in financing activities, and particularly by servicing debt, in terms of both interest and capital, and from all our payment obligations that result from business activities. Our liquidity management policy involves minimizing the available cash on a daily basis. The reimbursement capacity is reviewed annually. An adjustment during the year would be possible if necessary. In general, we manage our liquidity risk by monitoring our cash flow and rolling liquidity reserve forecast in order to ensure that we have sufficient facilities to meet our liquidity needs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is defined as the risk that any of the parties to a financial contract were to default on their contractual obligations, resulting in a loss to the other parties. Except for receivables under ‘‘other amounts receivable’’, we are not exposed to any significant credit risk with respect to our individual customers or business counterparties. There is also a credit risk in case a counterparty to a contract involving financial derivatives defaults on its obligations. We believe that this risk is limited given the creditworthiness of the counterparties with whom we enter into financial derivatives.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to various market risks, including interest rate, foreign currency exchange rate, credit and liquidity risks associated with our underlying assets, liabilities, forecast transactions and firm commitments. Our treasury department is responsible for managing our exposure to market risk that arises in connection with operations and financial activities, including interest rate, foreign currency exchange rate, credit and liquidity, and credit risk management. 84 ----- The following sections discuss our significant exposures to market risk. The following discussions do not address other risks that we face in the normal course of business, including country risk and legal risk.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of our financial statements requires our management to make judgments, estimates and assumptions about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. The estimates and associated assumptions are based on historical experience and other factors that are considered to be relevant. Actual results may differ from these estimates. The estimates and underlying assumptions are reviewed on an ongoing basis. Revisions to accounting estimates are recognized in the period in which the estimate is revised if the revision affects only that period, or in the period of the revision and future periods if the revision affects both current and future periods. 85 ----- The judgments, estimates and assumptions that management considers most critical are the following assumptions: - estimates and assumptions for measuring intangible assets at the time of acquisition, as well as estimates of their useful lives; - assessments of whether options to extend or not to terminate a lease agreement will be exercised; - calculations made to determine whether store impairment losses have to be recognized (tangible assets are assessed for impairment at the level of the individual stores); - calculations made to determine the recoverable amount of a cash-generating unit to which goodwill is allocated. The calculation of the recoverable amount is based on the estimated future cash flows and an appropriate discount rate has to be determined to calculate the present value; - reviewing the level of obsolescence of inventories and its impact on the expected net realizable value, being the estimated selling price in the ordinary course of business less the estimated costs to be incurred in bringing the inventories to their selling location and in selling condition, and consequently, the measurement of inventories; - reviewing the aging and collectability of trade receivables to calculate expected credit loss and determining the level of provisions for collectability; and - calculations made to determine the amount of current and deferred tax positions to be recognized. The calculation of the amount to be recognized is based on the estimated future taxable results and an estimate of the ultimate tax effect of certain transactions. 86 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following is a discussion and analysis of the results of operations and financial condition of Maxeda DIY Group for the six months ended August 2, 2020 and August 4, 2019, the years ended February 2, 2020, February 3, 2019 and January 31, 2018. See ‘‘Presentation of Financial and Other Data.’’ You should read this discussion in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements of Maxeda DIY Group and the accompanying notes included elsewhere in this offering memorandum as well as the ‘‘Selected Historical Financial Information.’’ A summary of the critical accounting estimates that have been applied to Maxeda DIY Group’s consolidated financial statements is set forth below in ‘‘—Critical accounting judgments.’’ This discussion also includes forward-looking statements which, although based on assumptions that we consider reasonable, are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual events or conditions to differ materially from those expressed or implied by the forward- looking statements, see ‘‘Forward-Looking Statements.’’ For a discussion of risks and uncertainties facing us as a result of various factors, see ‘‘Risk Factors.’’_

Subsection Title: Overview of the Belgian and Dutch DIY Markets
Subsubsection Text: The top-five DIY retailers in Belgium and the top-seven DIY superstores in the Netherlands had a combined market size of e6.0 billion as of July 2020, according to GfK. We believe that each of the Belgian and Dutch DIY markets have distinct characteristics as compared to the DIY markets in other Western European countries, and are also different from one another. The Belgian DIY market is characterized by a stable pricing environment, with limited pricing pressure among competitors. A comparatively high rate of home ownership in Belgium and a focus on larger-scale projects to improve home comfort are reflected in higher sales of ‘‘non-mobile’’ products. In-store shopping predominates in Belgium (with comparatively low online sales), with large-format ‘‘big box’’ stores particularly popular in this market, contributing to higher sales densities and resulting margins. By contrast, the Dutch market is primarily driven by trends in the housing market (i.e. home sales and new-builds), and by smaller-scale maintenance, repair and decoration projects such as painting and flooring. Accordingly, smaller-format, conveniently located stores and online sales are more popular in the Netherlands, with higher relative shares of sales as compared to the Belgian market. In both markets, DIY specialty retailers face limited competition from hypermarkets (defined as large, diversified non-specialist retailers such as Action, HEMA or IKEA) and pure-play online players, and we believe that strong barriers to entry in our markets mitigate the potential for increased competition. In particular, potential new market entrants face long lead times for potential new stores which we estimate to be between four to six years, attributable to the limited availability of prime retail locations and the lengthy planning and permitting processes in Belgium and the Netherlands. New entrants would face pressure from well-established competitors with greater brand recognition and broader networks in seeking to build a sustainable and profitable presence in these countries. We also view the technical complexity of many DIY products and the challenges of appropriately managing inventory space as additional barriers to entry in markets where product choice and accessibility are key customer considerations. The COVID-19 crisis impacted the Belgian and Dutch DIY markets in different ways. The Dutch DIY retailers received no government mandate to close their stores in March and April 2020, while Belgian DIY retailers had to close all stores for the period starting March 18, 2020 until April 17, 2020. Despite the pandemic crisis and the store closure for a one month period in Belgium, we have observed an increase in the DIY markets in both countries in 2020, due to increased customer focus on home improvement and DIY. We believe that the pandemic has impacted customer behavior, with renewed customer appreciation of and focus on home.

Subsection Title: DIY market trends in Belgium and the Netherlands
Subsubsection Text: We believe the trends outlined below are relevant in our markets and the development of our business. - Demographic changes: the overall growth in population and number of households is a driver of DIY spending, although the effect has been partly offset by a decrease in the number of people aged between 35 55, which is the age group that typically spends most time on home improvement. Consumer expenditure and the propensity of a population to change or improve their homes also constitute additional key drivers of the DIY spending. - Competition from pure play online retailers: increases in the DIY offering of pure play online retailers have a negative impact on traditional brick-and-mortar DIY incumbents. The share of Belgian and Dutch consumers buying DIY goods online, however, is still relatively limited 87 ----- (estimated for 2019 at approximately 6.5% in Belgium and approximately 10.6% in the Netherlands). The DIY market’s relatively low share of online sales in the Belgian and Dutch market are linked to a number of factors, including the dominance of in-store shopping (particularly in Belgium), DIY retailers’ late entry into the online channel and customer service requirements owing to the highly technical nature of many DIY products (i.e. advice on suitable product to solve a specific issue or meet a certain need). Nevertheless, online also plays a role in the DIY consumer market through product research, with significant customer trend for ‘‘Research Online, Purchase Offline (ROPO)’’. Major DIY retail chains are improving and expanding their online and omni-channel offerings, and should therefore be in a position to capture future online sales growth. - Indirect competition: diversification and growth from large non DIY retailers such as Action, HEMA or IKEA, generally present in both countries, has somewhat increased indirect competition with traditional DIY chains in certain product categories. However, this form of competition has not intensified recently, representing a stable and marginal share of the market, and Belgian and Dutch DIY specialty retailers have limited competition from hypermarkets. - Customer preference and focus on DIY and home improvement: DIY activity in Belgium and in the Netherlands has increased since the beginning of the COVID-19 outbreak, demonstrating enhanced customer focus on home improvement and DIY, especially small home repairs. This trend has been confirmed post lockdown and even during summer period, with catch-up effect on larger projects and repairs.

Robust macroeconomic development and stable consumer expenditure have historically underpinned the resilience of the Belgian DIY market. In contrast to the Dutch DIY market, the Belgian DIY market is characterized by a focus on larger renovation or home improvement projects (such as flooring, painting, windows, kitchen or bathroom), which form the core of the DIY retail market. The Belgian DIY market is estimated to represent approximately e2.2 billion in sales as of July 2020, having grown at a CAGR of 1.5% between 2014 and 2019, according to GfK. However, in the midst of the COVID-19 crisis, the size of the Belgian DIY market has significantly increased (+7.3% between December 2019 and July 2020), on the back of increased customer focus on home improvement and DIY, especially small home repairs.

Subsubsection Title: Impact of the COVID-19 outbreak in Belgium
Subsubsection Text: The Belgian government mandated closure of all stores for the period starting March 18, 2020 until April 17, 2020. Brico stores re-opened on April 18, 2020 and Plan-It stores on April 20, 2020. Following store re-openings, safety and health measures have been taken by DIY retailers in order to protect employees and customers. Belgian DIY retailers have benefited from COVID-19-related governmental 88 |2.04 1.89 1.91 1.95 1.94 1.98|Col2|Col3| |---|---|---| ----- support measures, which include technical unemployment and postponement or phasing of various tax payments (VAT, payroll tax). The DIY industry has experienced fast recovery at re-opening. Overall, DIY activity increased since the COVID-19 outbreak, mainly on the back of stronger appreciation and focus on the home. Although the demand from customers has risen above expectations, the long-term impact on our business is hard to predict and linked to the development of the COVID-19 crisis, which is still evolving and bringing many uncertainties.

Brico, Plan It, Hubo, Gamma and Mr. Bricolage, known as the ‘‘Big Five’’, are the largest players in the Belgian DIY market. We are the market leaders in the Belgian DIY market, with a combined market share across our two store brands (Brico and Plan-It) of approximately 46% of sales among the Big Five retailers in 2019 (44% in the twelve months ending July 2020). The Belgian DIY market can be differentiated between the northern and southern parts of the country (Dutch vs. French-speaking regions, respectively), each of which characterized by a different local competitive landscape. Mr. Bricolage is particularly strongly positioned in South, while Hubo and Gamma are well-established in the North. The Belgian DIY market is characterized by a stable pricing environment, with limited pricing pressure from competitors: DIY retailers mostly compete with independents, which tend to be less competitive in terms of price, and German retailers Hornbach and Bauhaus are not present in the country.

Subsubsection Title: Maxeda’s market share of the Belgian DIY market
Subsubsection Text: 10SEP202018085237 Source: GfK Note: Market size include sales of Big-5 Belgium DIY retailers (Brico, Plan-It, Briko Depot), Gamma, Brico and Mr. Bricolage

DIY has boosted overall home improvement growth in recent years, with the Dutch landscape having a substantial consumer group interested in DIY, who like to renovate, fix and build things around the house. These consumers dedicate their own time while saving costs through not hiring a professional, driving the bulk of revenue to home improvement retailers. A second consumer group that exists is made of those who prefer to hire professionals to complete home improvements and maintenance. This can range from extensive work, such as kitchen installation, to small tasks for maintenance people; such as hanging a lamp or installing a shelf. As the economy strengthens, this group tends to grow in the Netherlands, which we believe can put increasing pressure on home improvement players. The Dutch DIY market is estimated to represent approximately e3.8 billion in sales as of July 2020, having grown at a CAGR of 5.4% between 2014 and 2019, according to GfK. The growth of market size has been sizable in the midst of the COVID-19 crisis, with an increase of 14.8% between December 2019 and July 2020, on the back of increased customer focus on home improvement and DIY. 89 10SEP202018085237 -----

Subsubsection Title: Impact of the COVID-19 outbreak in the Netherlands
Subsubsection Text: In the Dutch DIY market, stores remained open as Dutch government decided not to mandate closure of stores in regard to COVID-19 safety. The DIY market has benefited from this resolution, as consumers have increased DIY activity during the pandemic situation. Dutch DIY physical stores have experienced increase in both the number of customers and ticket size. In that context, safety and health measures have been taken by DIY retailers in order to protect employees and customers. When applicable, Dutch DIY retailers have benefited from COVID-related governmental support measures, which include technical unemployment and postponement or phasing of various tax payments (VAT, payroll tax).

Large DIY retail chains, such as Praxis, Gamma and Karwei and German retailers Hornbach or Bauhaus are the main competitors in the Dutch DIY market. Maxeda has the second largest combined market share through Praxis, with approximately 26% of sales of the Dutch DIY market (as defined by GfK) in 2019 (approximately 25% for the twelve months ending July 2020); behind leading group Intergamma (operating under the Gamma and Karwei brands). The market is fairly concentrated, with Maxeda and Intergamma being the clear leader, well ahead of the rest of competition. The rest of the market is essentially composed of small and local independent players.
