_Overview_ The following table presents the location and number of our franchisee-operated stores as of August 2, 2020:

Praxis . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 151 Total . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** 227 104 ----- Our stores are fitted to what we believe is the optimum standard given their space and building configuration, but we continue to work on improving product presentation within our directly operated stores and typically refurbish our directly operated stores on an as-needed basis. Store refurbishment and fixture innovation typically drive revenue growth at a faster rate than stores that have not received similar investment, and we selectively undertake refurbishments varying in scale, including by introducing updated store concepts, new store formats or by converting existing stores to a different Maxeda brand. Our refurbished stores have historically experienced an increase in sales, outperforming the average network store in a comparable one-year period following the refurbishment. Such refurbishments, however, may have an adverse impact on profitability during the refurbishment period. We expect to continue the strategic optimization of our store network over time through rebranding and store refurbishment, including the conversion of stores to our new store concepts and formats. We invested approximately e1.3 million in the Netherlands and e9.5 million in Belgium on in-store refurbishment in the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. In 2020, we plan to complete substantial refurbishments of approximately eight additional stores, including one of our BricoPlanit stores, four Brico stores and three Praxis stores. We also regularly refurbish individual departments in our BricoPlanit stores as part of our larger refurbishment program for that store brand, and we intend to refurbish between two and three selected Brico stores per year over the next three years. Praxis . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 44 Total . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** 121 Our BricoPlanit stores do not operate as franchises, but we have franchisee-operated stores under our Brico and Praxis store brands. As of August 2, 2020, our franchisee-operated stores were owned and operated by an aggregate of 86 franchisees, with the largest franchisee operating 6 stores. Historically, franchisees enabled us to quickly add significant scale at a low investment rate. Our franchisee-operated stores conform to our standardized store layout that we have established for each store brand and offer a predetermined range of SKUs tailored to that store brand, as adjusted to reflect the location’s specific attributes. From the customer’s perspective, there are generally no visible differences between our directly operated stores and franchisee-operated stores. _Franchise agreements_ Across our three store brands, we had 121 stores under franchise agreements with 86 unique franchise partners as of August 2, 2020. Our standard franchise agreement varies by store brand, but generally allows franchisees to carry and use our brand names. Under our arrangements with our franchisees, we supply products and operational support to the franchisee-operated stores. For instance, we may enter into a head lease with respect to a store location and sublet such property to a franchisee to the extent necessary for our franchisees to secure suitable premises for operating one of our franchises. We work together with our franchisees to agree on which product offerings are best suited to each local market and, in Belgium, our franchisees can choose to externally source up to 10% of their in-store product offering. The success of our franchisee-operated stores requires our franchisees to have a strong, well-funded capital base and local retail knowledge to support the initial store launch. Under certain separate agreements with our franchisees or their lenders, we may enter into buyback commitments whereby we undertake to repurchase inventory and stock from a franchisee or its lender in the event the franchisee defaults under its financing arrangements with local banks. Typically, these financing arrangements are entered into in connection with store openings and inventory purchases. Previously, in limited circumstances, we repurchased inventory from certain of our franchisees or their 105 ----- lenders, but were able to utilize this inventory in other stores in our network. We believe our relations with our franchisees are good. In addition, we are responsible for funding and implementing national marketing campaigns and organizing in-store marketing for all our stores, including franchisee-operated stores (as funded by the franchise fee we charge our franchisees). We do not have specific advertisement programs in place for franchisees in their local markets and do not incur capital expenditures in relation to the franchiseeoperated stores, as those costs are committed and paid directly by franchisees. We do not include franchisee costs when recording our own capital expenditures. In limited circumstances, we may incur certain capital expenditures on behalf of our franchisees, primarily in relation to the expansion of our franchisee-operated stores in Belgium, in which case our contribution would typically range between e0.1 million and e0.4 million per year. We also incurred certain capital expenditures in relation to the conversion of certain franchisee-operated Formido stores to the Praxis brand. Because we do not incur significant capital expenditures in connection with opening new franchisee-operated stores and, therefore, carry less financial risk, franchisee-operated stores allow us to expand our network more quickly than we would if we opened directly operated stores. In particular, our franchise network allows us to improve proximity to our customers in smaller towns and villages. We select franchise partners that demonstrate an ability to secure entry into appropriate prime retail locations, to trade in accordance with our high operating standards and to grow the business in line with our mutually agreed business plans. From time to time, our franchisees may be required to make capital expenditures to refresh the layout of their stores and to fund operational updates, including for IT. Products ordered through our digital channel and collected by customers in a franchisee store are recorded as sales performed in the store of that franchisee. From time to time, our franchisees’ performance may fall below our jointly agreed performance levels or a franchisee may fail to pay for inventory or certain mandatory fees. In such cases, we generally work with our franchisees to seek performance improvements or work out arrangements to receive payments in line with our contractual rights. If we are unsuccessful, we may then seek to exit the contractual relationship or to buy the store from the franchisee. Historically, we believe that we have had good relationships with franchisees, with the majority of our franchisees opting for renewal upon the expiration of their agreements. Generally our franchise agreements provide us with a consent right in connection with any assignment by the franchisee and a right of first refusal in favor of us if the relevant franchisee would like to sell their business. In addition, the franchise agreement may, in certain circumstances, be terminated if the store manager or owner changes. To protect our store brands, the franchise agreements also usually place non-compete and non-solicitation restrictions on the franchisee, at least for the duration of the contract and sometimes for a one-year period following the termination of the franchise agreement. Brico We had 77 Brico stores operating under franchise agreements with 56 unique franchise partners as of August 2, 2020. The Brico franchise agreements have a standard term of nine years and provide for a renewal consultation twelve to 18 months prior to expiration. In our Brico franchisee-operated stores, fees consist of a one-off fee to Brico, fees for operational support and certain commission fees, based on a fixed percentage of Brico’s related supply and logistic costs. In addition to the payment of the fees as described above, our Brico franchisees are also further required to provide premises for the stores and to purchase stock directly from us and our agreed suppliers as they deem fit. Brico franchisees can choose to externally source up to 10% of their in-store product offering. The Brico franchisees are represented by their own committee (Committee de Concertation) and Brico is required to consult the committee before taking important decisions that will impact the franchise formula. Under Belgian law, Brico is required to make substantial pre-contractual information disclosures in its capacity as franchisor before a franchise agreement is executed. We have instituted policies and procedures to ensure our compliance with the relevant disclosure requirements, including the use of a standardized pre-contractual information document, which we complete with specific information on each franchiseeoperated Brico store and divulge in each instance Brico is required to make such disclosure. In the event of noncompliance, the franchisee can invoke the nullity of the agreement up to two years after the execution of the agreement. As of August 2, 2020, there were seven franchise agreements within the first two years of their execution in Belgium, and there had been no material proceedings based on noncompliance with these requirements. 106 ----- Praxis We had 44 Praxis stores operating under franchise agreements with 30 franchise partners as of August 2, 2020. The Praxis franchise agreements have a standard term of five years with an automatic renewal period of five years after such initial term and a one-year termination notice period, which may be exercised by either party following this five-year term. The franchisee pays us a single fee calculated as a percentage of its turnover. Praxis franchisees have a right of first refusal with respect to opening additional Praxis stores in their exclusive area. Under the franchise agreements, the franchisee is required to provide premises for the stores and to purchase at least a minimum amount of stock from us based on expected volume requirements calculated by Praxis’s automated stock management systems. Praxis franchisees are in principle not permitted to offer deviating merchandise and services. The Praxis franchisees are represented by their own committee (Vereniging Praxis Aangesloten Bedrijven) which must approve certain changes to the Praxis ‘‘franchise formula,’’ which consists of several elements described in the Praxis franchise agreements, including the look and feel of the franchisee-operated store, the technical know-how provided by us and the product assortment range. As of August 2, 2020, there were eleven franchise agreements within the first two years of their execution in the Netherlands, and there had been no material proceedings based on noncompliance with these requirements.

We are a leading DIY retailer in Belgium and the Netherlands. For the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, we had the largest combined share of the Belgian DIY Market through our Brico and BricoPlanit brands, with a market share of approximately 44% of the Belgian DIY Market based on Transactional Sales. In the Netherlands, we estimate that we had the second largest combined share of the Dutch DIY Superstores Market through our Praxis brand, with a market share of approximately 25% based on Transactional Sales. Our store portfolio consists of directly operated stores and franchisee-operated stores trading under three store brands: Brico, BricoPlanit, and Praxis. As of August 2, 2020, our store portfolio included 348 stores (including 121 franchisee-operated stores), comprising 195 stores in the Netherlands under our Praxis brand and 150 stores in Belgium and three stores in Luxembourg under our Brico and BricoPlanit brands. During the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, our directly operated stores (including Click & Collect) accounted for 83% of our revenue, our franchisee-operated stores accounted for 15% of our revenue and our online sales (excluding Click & Collect) accounted for 2% of our revenue. An overview of our store brands is set forth below: Brico:_** We directly operate 60 stores in Belgium and three stores in Luxembourg, and our franchisees operate 77 stores in Belgium under the Brico brand and the Briko Depot and _Brico City sub-brands. Established in 1973, Brico is the DIY market leader in Belgium, with a market share of approximately 29% in the Belgian DIY Market in terms of Transactional Sales for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, according to GfK. Brico offers a wide range of DIY, home decoration and garden products with 28,000 to 50,000 SKUs stocked per store. The average floor surface area of our directly operated Brico stores is approximately 3,300 square meters and the average floor surface area of our franchisee-operated Brico stores is approximately 1,800 square meters. Brico’s three largest product groups are paint, paint specialties and accessories, and hardware. Brico accounted for 31% of our revenue for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. BricoPlanit:_** We directly operate all 13 of our ‘‘Big Box’’ stores in Belgium under the BricoPlanit brand, the only pure DIY Big Box format in Belgium. Established in 2004, our BricoPlanit brand is known for its chain of DIY megastores in Belgium with a market share of approximately 15% in the Belgian DIY Market in terms of Transactional Sales for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, according to GfK. BricoPlanit offers a large range of products for home improvement projects, with approximately 49,000 SKUs stocked per store and an average floor surface area of approximately 9,000 square meters. BricoPlanit’s three largest product groups are indoor and construction products, flooring and building materials. BricoPlanit accounted for 19% of our revenue for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. Praxis:_** We directly operate 151 stores and our franchisees operate 44 stores in the Netherlands under the Praxis brand and the _Praxis Mega & Garden, Praxis Mega and_ _Praxis City sub-brands. Established in 1978, Praxis is our leading DIY concept in the Netherlands, with a market share of approximately 25% of the Dutch DIY Superstores Market in terms of Transactional Sales for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, according to GfK. Praxis offers a broad product assortment that varies by store size, ranging from 8,000 to 65,000 SKUs stocked per store. The floor surface area of our Praxis stores varies from approximately 300 square meters for our _Praxis City ‘‘City’’ stores to approximately 11,900 square meters for our large-format _Praxis Mega & Garden stores. The floor surface area of our ‘‘standard’’ Praxis stores is approximately 3,000 square meters for directly operated stores and approximately 2,900 square meters for franchiseeoperated stores. Praxis’s largest product groups are paint, flooring, and indoor and construction products. Praxis accounted for 50% of our revenue for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. 91 ----- We operate our three brands across three store formats, ‘‘City’’ stores, ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores and ‘‘Big Box’’ stores, through which we target distinct customers and project requirements. Each of our store formats offers a unique focus: City Stores:_** Our ‘‘City’’ stores, consisting of our _Brico City and_ _Praxis City sub-brands, in Belgium and the Netherlands, respectively, are located in city centers. These stores are generally small in size and focus on providing convenient access to products for routine, small-scale maintenance and repair projects, targeting both first-time and more experienced DIY consumers with basic home repair or improvement needs. Mid Box Stores:_** Our ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores consist of our Brico stores in Belgium and our Praxis stores in the Netherlands. These stores are larger in size and provide a wider range of products for larger maintenance, repair, decoration and renovation projects, targeting both first-time and more experienced DIY consumers undertaking decorative or home improvement projects that might require more resources than our ‘‘City’’ stores can provide. Big Box Stores:_** Our ‘‘Big Box’’ stores consist of our BricoPlanit stores in Belgium and our Praxis Mega and Praxis Mega & Garden stores in the Netherlands. These stores are our largest, and provide our most extensive range of products for a variety of home improvement projects, primarily targeting consumers experienced in DIY projects who are shopping for more-technical products for large DIY projects and for more-expensive decorative items. Our digital distribution channel is growing, with over 40 million online visits and e34 million in online sales (excluding Click & Collect), or 2% of our revenue, for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. We operate our digital distribution channel through two websites, one for our Brico and BricoPlanit brands in Belgium and one for our Praxis brand in the Netherlands, in order to meet customer demand for an omnichannel shopping experience and provide greater and more convenient access to our products. In addition to traditional home delivery services, all of our store brands offer a ‘‘Click & Reserve’’ option, which allows customers to order products that do not require assembly or which the customer decides to assemble themselves online and pick up in-store, and a ‘‘Click & Collect’’ option, which allows customers to order products that require assembly and pick them up in store after they have been assembled by our specialists, each of which we believe increases the likelihood of additional or ancillary purchases by the customer. We have also opened a distribution center exclusively dedicated to our online sales. Through our Brico, BricoPlanit and Praxis digital channels, we also provide the option of Drop Shipment, whereby products are shipped directly from the supplier to the customer’s home. We aim to continue to develop our mobile phone and tablet applications across our store brands, enhancing the way we present our products to users and increasing the channels through which consumers can purchase them. We aim to offer our customers a strong value proposition through a comprehensive product assortment across five product categories: (i) decorating, which includes painting and lighting products, (ii) building, which includes wood, flooring and doors, (iii) tools, electrical and hardware, which includes drills and other tools and instruments, (iv) gardening, which includes garden power tools, outdoors furniture and garden wood products, and (v) installation, sanitary and kitchen, which includes plumbing products, taps and heating instruments. We aim to maximize customer choice through a multi-brand strategy that combines a wide offering of top-level branded products selectively complemented by our private label products. In the year ended February 2, 2020, we derived 74% of our Transactional Sales from third-party branded products and the remaining 26% from our private label products. For the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, we generated Transactional Sales of e1,976 million, revenue of e1,483 million, Adjusted EBITDA of e240 million, Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16) of e151 million, and had an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 16.2% and an Adjusted EBITDA margin (pre-IFRS 16) of 10.2%. Our business performed well during the COVID-19 pandemic and we benefitted from the successful implementation of the first two phases of a three-phase strategic plan that we initiated in 2016, which included initiatives such as the development of our e-commerce platform. Our revenue for the six months ended August 2, 2020, increased by e93 million, or 12%, to e861 million, from e768 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019, primarily due to an increase in Like-for-Like Sales by 15.3% over the period, as a result of increased consumer focus on DIY projects due to increased time 92 ----- spent at home and in their gardens as a result of lockdown measures implemented in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, during which our stores in the Netherlands remained open and our stores in Belgium closed for only one month between March and April.

Subsubsection Title: Leader in a growing DIY market with a strong store network
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading DIY retailer in Belgium and the Netherlands, with strong and stable market positions underpinned by a dense network of 348 stores across multiple retail formats and brands that cater to a diverse range of DIY customers and needs. We have adapted to evolving consumer habits by opening smaller outlets in city centers and by investing in our online presence. We have an extensive footprint of 150 Brico and BricoPlanit stores in Belgium and 195 Praxis stores in the Netherlands and also operate three Brico stores in Luxembourg. According to data compiled by GfK, our Brico and BricoPlanit store brands held a combined market share of approximately 44% of the Belgian DIY Market for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. We have a particularly strong presence in selected highly populated regions such as Brussels where, according to a retail marketing agency, Brico and BricoPlanit represented an estimated 90% of market share by Transactional Sales for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. We also enjoy a strong position in the Netherlands, where we estimate that we are the second-largest DIY retailer in terms of Transactional Sales, with a total of 195 stores trading under our well-established Praxis brand and a combined market share of 25% of the Dutch DIY Superstores Market for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. We have benefitted from our online strategy and omnichannel capabilities, in particular during the COVID-19 outbreak. Our market share in Belgium and the Netherlands is supported by our long-standing presence, extensive market knowledge and strong brand visibility in these markets. We believe that the insight gained from our extensive trading history in Belgium and the Netherlands is a competitive advantage relative to new market entrants, because it positions us to identify prime retail locations and capitalize on local customer preferences.

Subsubsection Title: High degree of diversification providing resilience and stability
Subsubsection Text: We operate a diversified multi-format, multi-brand and multi-channel retail platform designed to serve the varying needs of DIY customers across Belgium and the Netherlands. Our physical network of 348 stores across Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg comprises stores with three distinct but complementary value propositions tailored to their respective geographic regions and target customers. Our ‘‘City’’ stores are designed for maximum convenience, with small surface areas in high population density locations and a specialized product range focused on immediate maintenance and repair needs. Our ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores are larger in size, with an emphasis on a superior in-store experience and an extensive range of DIY, home decoration and gardening products for small and large projects. Our ‘‘Big Box’’ stores are destination stores offering our widest array of products, including those required for large-scale renovations and decorative projects. The broad product offering across each of our three store formats is complemented by knowledgeable staff and expert advice tailored to the product category and specific customer need. Our complementary store formats, expert in-store advice and tailored product offerings allow us to service the full range of our customers’ DIY requirements, from one-off convenience purchases to large projects. We have also developed a ‘‘Do-It-For-Me’’ platform in Belgium and the Netherlands through which customers can find third-party professionals who can perform their DIY jobs. We allow these professionals to register on our platform and we then let customers pick the specialist they need. We aim to offer our customers a strong value proposition through a comprehensive product assortment across product categories. Our stores stock well-established brands such as Grohe, Gardena, Black & Decker, Akzo, Bosch, Knauf, Flexa and Signify. We also have distribution arrangements in place with certain key suppliers to distribute certain of their branded products exclusively in our stores and online in Belgium and the Netherlands. We seek to differentiate ourselves from competitors and to boost our range innovation by also offering our private label products as alternatives or complements to our branded offering in certain product categories such as power tools, hand tools and gardening products. With our private label products, we aim to offer equivalent quality and superior value to comparable branded products at a variety of price points through our ‘‘good,’’ ‘‘better’’ and ‘‘best’’ product ranges. The margins generated on our private label products are on average approximately 23% higher than the margins on the equivalent branded products we sell. For the year ended February 2, 2020 we generated 74% of our Transactional Sales from third-party branded products and 26% of our Transactional Sales from our private label products. This extensive and flexible 93 ----- product offering differentiates us from smaller competitors and allows us to optimize sales of trending DIY products.

Subsubsection Title: Dynamic business model based on a strong and flexible operating platform
Subsubsection Text: Our store portfolio consists of a mix of 65% directly operated stores and 35% franchisee-operated stores, providing operational flexibility across our different formats with the goal of maximizing our profitability in each market. We selectively open new stores in localities where we are not present and where we have identified demand for our products. Our franchise arrangements enable us to reduce the risk associated with growing our network and expanding into new localities. We seek franchise partners with the relevant expertise, specialized market knowledge and local networks required to rapidly succeed in each market, and we permit our franchisees limited flexibility to tailor a portion of their product offering to specialized local demands. However, we maintain robust, centralized control over our stores, products and messaging, thereby ensuring consistent product offerings and the uniform implementation of display and marketing initiatives across all stores. Through this combination of directly operated stores and franchisee-operated stores, we are able to efficiently leverage our well-known store brands and extend our geographic reach. We have selectively sought to convert franchisee stores to directly operated stores in selected formats during the past three years in line with our store optimization focus, and the percentage of our stores that are directly owned has increased from 53% as of April 30, 2017 to 65% as of August 2, 2020. Our brick-and-mortar stores are complemented by our two websites for the Brico and BricoPlanit brands and the Praxis brands allowing us to reach customers who may prefer to order online and who have difficulties in reaching our stores. Our extensive store network and online product offering is supplied by an efficient, diversified and flexible sourcing model that we believe, combined with the large scale of our operations, helps us to obtain favorable commercial terms with our key suppliers and preserve our margins. In recent years, we have made substantial investments in streamlining our supply chain, including the consolidation of procurement functions for Brico, BricoPlanit and Praxis in an effort to maximize synergies between our brands and leverage their combined scale in negotiations with suppliers. Our vendor management team also benefits from the A.R.E.N.A. Alliance, a procurement partnership with seven other retail groups focused on the sourcing and negotiation of supplies of DIY, garden and home improvement products. As of August 2, 2020, we sourced our products from diversified base of over 700 suppliers located primarily in Belgium, the Netherlands and Asia, compared to 900 as of April 30, 2017. We have developed our own Asian sourcing platform since 2011, which we renamed Surity. Surity negotiates and contracts directly with Asia-based suppliers through an office in Shanghai, China. We have been able to leverage knowledge of local markets through this partnership, which also improved our profitability as direct sourcing results in higher margins. In addition, we have implemented a margin enhancement program with the aim of building longer-term relationships with our key suppliers, reducing costs, optimizing the efficiency of our supplier base, concentrating spend and ensuring the quality and security of the supply for a number of our key products. Our procurement initiatives are supported by our SITI program, a lean inventory policy aiming to structurally decrease stock and improve working capital. We have minimized our inventory footprint, operating a single central warehouse (located between Antwerp and Brussels), which supplies our stores in both Belgium and the Netherlands with most of our products. This central warehouse is complemented by a smaller specialized warehouse in Ninove, Belgium, which supplies our stores with wood and construction products, and two ‘‘flow through’’ dock centers (one in Vianen, the Netherlands and one in Bornem, Belgium), which have helped us to efficiently manage our inventory and reduce our distribution costs. We also have a new distribution center in Roermond, the Netherlands, exclusively dedicated to the delivery of products ordered through our online sales channels, the operation of which we have contracted to a third party. We occupy approximately 100,000 square meters of warehouse space. As of August 2, 2020, approximately 24,000 SKUs are delivered through this dedicated e-commerce distribution center.

Subsubsection Title: Successful strategic initiatives have strengthened our business
Subsubsection Text: We initiated a three phase strategic improvement plan in 2016 which focused on optimizing our business, and we believe that the successful implementation of the first two phases has enabled us to grow revenue, Like-for-Like Sales and Adjusted EBITDA, has reduced operating expenses and working capital, and helped us to perform well during the COVID-19 crisis. 94 ----- Our ‘‘Back to Simplicity’’ strategy was initiated in 2016 with the aim of optimizing functions and reducing costs across our business, and was completed in 2018. Among other things, our ‘‘Back to Simplicity’’ strategy focused on terminating the Praxis Garden franchise format by closing our three remaining Praxis Garden stores in 2017, simplifying our administrative functions by centralizing our headquarters in Belgium and relocating our Amsterdam headquarters, reducing our fixed cost base by renegotiating rents at many of our Praxis stores and investing in our employees and their ability to increase customer satisfaction including by offering general and specialized DIY knowledge, renegotiating our collective bargaining agreement in Belgium, and reducing our electricity costs through the installation of LED lighting at our stores and offices. We initiated the second phase of our plan, our ‘‘Back to Basics’’ strategy in 2017, with the aim of enhancing our customer value proposition through the creation of a new cohesive store format across our Brico, BricoPlanit and Praxis brands, reinforcing our positioning in key product categories, enhancing efficiency of operations and customer service and building commitment from our employees through employee investment, training and empowerment. We have improved the visual identity of our stores and have sought to optimize our inventory offering by conducting a range review across all formats. We have launched a leadership path for store employees and implemented systems to train our employees to be more familiar with our products. In addition, we conducted reviews our store portfolio across all brands, resulting in the opening of 17 new stores, the relocation of four existing stores and the remodeling of six existing stores. As a result of these initiatives, we operate a profitable portfolio of stores and for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, we had only two stores with negative Adjusted EBITDA in Belgium and one store with negative Adjusted EBITDA in the Netherlands. Other stores that had been loss making in prior periods have either been converted to newly-opened City stores in the Netherlands or closed or sold to franchisees in Belgium. We have also identified specific initiatives for the remaining stores with negative Adjusted EBITDA, such as rent renegotiation, active marketing campaign or store closure. We also successfully phased out our Formido brand in the Netherlands. We converted 40 of our Formido stores into Praxis stores, refurbishing these stores and the products they offer to reflect the Praxis brand image, sold 23 stores, and closed the remaining 11 Formido stores. This initiative strengthened our Praxis brand, and we have maintained our market share in the Netherlands through the conversion process. All of our stores in the Netherlands are now operated under the Praxis brand. After conversion to the Praxis brand, the 30 best-performing converted Formido stores has experienced an average gross margin increase of 25% per store for the year ended February 3, 2019, compared to the year ended January 31, 2018, with the five best-performing converted Formido stores experiencing increases in gross margins of 50% on average. We also successfully completed our e-commerce optimization as part of our ‘‘Back to Basics’’ strategy, and have become the leading DIY omnichannel retailer in Benelux, with a variety of sales and delivery channels and the development of our two new, more flexible and mobile-friendly, websites designed to maximize the accessibility of our products. We have invested in the features and functionality of our branded online channels in an effort to diversify our revenue streams and capture a greater share of the growing DIY e-commerce market in Belgium and the Netherlands. For example, we combined the two websites for our Brico and BricoPlanit brands in Belgium, and we now have one website for our Brico and BricoPlanit brands for the Belgian market and one website for our Praxis brand for the Dutch market. These websites offer online ordering capabilities and detailed information on our products. We have also opened a distribution center exclusively dedicated to the delivery of products ordered through our online sales channels in order to improve the speed and efficiency of our delivery of online orders. The expansion of our digital platform and the integration of online capabilities into our physical stores, such as in-store tablets and Wi-Fi access points in all our stores for the ordering of products unavailable in stores, has also had a positive impact on our profitability, as it is less costly to fulfill orders that are picked up in our stores through our Click & Collect and Click & Reserve services than orders that are delivered directly to our customers. We also focus on community interaction, and distribute inspirational DIY videos explaining DIY techniques to our customers and potential customers in order to increase brand loyalty and showcase products available in our stores. We have also increased our social media coverage to enable interaction with customers and improve after sale communications. 95 -----

Subsubsection Title: Resilience demonstrated through the COVID-19 outbreak
Subsubsection Text: Our business performed well during the COVID-19 outbreak, in part due to consumer focus on DIY projects while in lockdown or working from home. Even though governments in Belgium and the Netherlands implemented measures to contain the spread of the virus and these measures affected our business operations, along with those of other retailers in the markets in which we operate, the growth of Belgian and Dutch DIY markets significantly accelerated since the beginning of 2020. This was partly due to the COVID-19 outbreak, which resulted in strong customer focus on home improvements and DIY projects, especially small home repairs. This trend accelerated when governments eased lockdown measures in June 2020, with customers in Belgium resuming DIY projects that they were unable to complete due to the closure of stores in Belgium, as illustrated in the following graphs (according to GfK): 10SEP202018085811 While we initially experienced a substantial decrease in sales in Belgium due to store closures, our stores subsequently experienced sales growth in late April, May and June, and sales in those months were higher than for the comparative months in 2019, primarily due to increased DIY activity as a result of our customers spending more time at home and in their gardens. Our stores in the Netherlands remained open throughout the pandemic, with limited opening hours, and performed well, and our sales in the Netherlands for the period from March to June were higher than for the comparable period in 2019, as customers increasingly focused on DIY home improvements, which we presume resulted from increased time spent at home as well as adapting the home space for additional functions including school and work. We incurred e9 million in costs incurred for additional health and safety measures in our stores during the six months ended August 2, 2020. We believe that the improvements implemented as part of our strategic initiatives, allowed us to take advantage of this trend and contributed to our business’ strong performance during the COVID-19 outbreak. For example, most of the Formido stores that we converted to Praxis are small stores that 96 10SEP202018085811 ----- consumers favored during the pandemic outbreak, which confirmed our strategy to focus on a diversified multi-format platform. We also benefitted from our e-commerce optimization strategy over the last three years and the investments in our product range availability, as online shopping and delivery increased during the outbreak. Our online sales (excluding Click & Collect) in Belgium increased by 350% for the six months ended August, 2, 2020, compared to the same period in 2019, and online sales (excluding Click & Collect) also significantly increased in the Netherlands, with an increase of 23% for the six months ended August, 2, 2020, compared to the same period in 2019. We believe that the COVID-19 outbreak and subsequent government measures have contributed to an increased consumer focus on home and garden improvements, and we believe this will be a long-term trend with a positive impact our operations.

Subsubsection Title: Improved operating performance leading to deleveraging
Subsubsection Text: As a result of the strength of our business and the success of our strategic initiatives, since 2017 our business has steadily grown, our margins have improved and we have maintained strong cash conversion. From the year ended January 31, 2018 to the year ended February 2, 2020, our revenues grew at a CAGR of 1% and we maintained strong growth in profitability, with Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16) growing at a CAGR of 9% during that period. For the years ended January 31, 2018, February 3, 2019 and February 2, 2020 and the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, our Gross Profit Margins were 34.5%, 34.8%, 36.0% and 36.7%, respectively, and our Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16) margins were 6.9%, 8.2%, 8.0% and 10.2%, respectively. We have demonstrated that the investments in our various initiatives to revamp our business have delivered strong cash flow generation, even through the COVID-19 outbreak. Cash Flow Conversion for the years ended January 31, 2018, February 3, 2019 and February 2, 2020, and for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020 was 128%, 124%, 112% and 108%, respectively. We focus on actively managing our working capital to further improve our cash generation, and since 2018 our inventory optimization program has positively impacted our change in operating working capital. For instance, for the six months ended August 2, 2020, our change in adjusted net working capital amounted to e138 million. Our level of maintenance capital expenditure (which includes store refurbishments and product range reviews) was stable at e24 million, e27 million and e27 million for the years ended February 2, 2020, February 3, 2019 and January 31, 2018, respectively, and could be reduced slightly if necessary in the event of a decrease in Adjusted EBITDA. Our financial resilience, in the face of a challenging economic environment following the outbreak of COVID-19, has been due in part to the innovative, cost-saving initiatives implemented by our leadership team, which have strengthened our fundamentals and streamlined our business.

Subsubsection Title: Strong management team committed to sustainable development
Subsubsection Text: We have a highly experienced and professional senior management team headed by Guy Colleau, our Chief Executive Officer, who benefits from more than 30 years of international consumer and retail experience. Our Chief Financial Officer, Luc Leunis, has held executive positions in our group for almost 20 years and benefits from 25 years of retail experience. Our management team has significant experience in the retail and DIY industries, a deep understanding of the Belgian and Dutch markets and an excellent track record of executing strategic objectives. Through a comprehensive review of our leadership position in the Belgian and Dutch DIY markets, our customer value propositions and the management of our operations, our senior management team also successfully implemented our ‘‘Back to Simplicity,’’ ‘‘Back to Basics’’ and ‘‘Make-it-Easy’’ strategic plans, which have remodeled our business and increased our profitability. Our management team believes that sustainable development with positive impact on the environment and on society will prove rewarding on the long-term, and we aspire to do business as a responsible corporate citizen. We are committed to a sound governance structure and operate a supervisory board that consists of both investors and external directors. We seek to respect people and the planet and uphold values and ethical standards. We offer our customers the possibility of delivering old batteries, tools, bulbs and electrical waste that we subsequently dispose of in a sustainable manner and continuously seek to improve the sustainability of our sourcing and reduce our carbon footprint. Our management team has implemented initiatives throughout our business operations to increase their sustainability, such as increased use of sustainable products and reduced use of disposable packaging. 97 -----

Subsubsection Title: Continuing to improve our operating performance through effective cost management and working capital optimization
Subsubsection Text: We plan to continue to reduce costs and optimize our use of working capital in order to maintain and enhance our cost position and improve our operating performance and profitability, in line with the ‘‘Back to Simplicity’’ and ‘‘Back to Basics’’ phases of our strategic improvement plan. Our ‘‘Make-it-Easy’’ strategy also aims to, among other things, further improve our cost savings and optimize our use of working capital. Cost-saving initiatives include the installation of self-scanning desks for self-checkout at our stores, synergies in our Brico and BricoPlanit marketing costs, increasing the sourcing of our private-label products and reduced storage times between the offloading of incoming supplies and their onwards reshipment. We continuously seek to improve our cost base which in turn allows us to offer compelling pricing to our customers, including through partnerships such as the A.R.E.N.A. Alliance to negotiate better terms with suppliers. We also intend to reduce the cost of our utilities and reevaluate certain of our maintenance and repair contracts. We also aim to improve our working capital requirements. Our working capital optimization initiatives include further strengthening relationships with certain preferred suppliers and the rollout of our SITI program, which will enhance our inventory management by, for example, allowing us to return to certain relationship suppliers of certain products that we have not sold at the end of a promotion campaign. We also encourage members of certain teams and committees to meet specific cost reduction and productivity improvement targets each year, with a material amount of their compensation tied to their performance against these targets. We require that capital projects meet certain return thresholds, which encourages prudent levels of spending on expansion and cost-saving opportunities.

Subsubsection Title: Reinforce our positioning in each of our product categories with a comprehensive product offering at compelling prices
Subsubsection Text: We aim to further strengthen our position by continuing to perform full reviews and optimizations of our product range to better tailor our offering to customer demands. We perform these reviews periodically for each product category to identify, stock and market products which we believe have high growth potential or reflect consumer trends. We then prioritize the visibility of these product categories in our stores and on our website. For example, we aim to increase our standing as a specialist in certain key product categories, such as ‘‘non-mobile’’ products and tools for larger home improvement and installation projects, by showcasing these products in our stores more often. We also intend to further increase the product density in our ‘‘City’’ stores by reducing the width of store aisles to increase SKUs carried and showcase more of our product offering. In our ‘‘Mid Box’’ and ‘‘City’’ stores, in which due to store size our product range is necessarily more limited compared to our ‘‘Big Box’’ stores, we have scaled our product range more appropriately to customer demand, offering a strategic selection of SKUs per product category in order to efficiently service customer demand while managing our inventory levels. Furthermore, we have used and intend to continue to use a range of targeted promotions to highlight our capabilities as a multi-specialist retailer and comprehensive DIY solutions provider. Our upcoming promotion initiatives include sale days on which we provide certain discounts across all product categories, as well as promotional events targeting specific seasonal or product categories, particularly in our ‘‘Big Box’’ stores. For instance, ‘‘wood month’’ will promote our capabilities as a wood products specialist, and ‘‘gardening days’’ will showcase for customers our comprehensive and compelling range of outdoor products.

Subsubsection Title: Enhancing our operational efficiency and customer service by leveraging our digital platform
Subsubsection Text: As part of our ‘‘Make-it-Easy’’ strategy, we intend to (i) leverage our e-commerce activities to move into markets where we are currently not present by expanding the reach of our websites internationally to commercialize our private label and exclusive brands in these markets, such as in France, (ii) invest in high quality content to increase search engine optimization and search engine advertising, (iii) continue to increase the amount of SKUs available on our online stores, (iv) launch a product locator app, and 98 ----- (v) increase the amount of orders that can be fulfilled through either Drop Shipment or through our dedicated e-commerce distribution platform. All our product ranges are available on our digital platform and we have further expanded the availability of SKUs on our websites through the development of our Drop Shipment Model, through which certain suppliers deliver products directly to the consumer’s home. We are working on making all SKUs that are available in-store available online, and are also expanding our catalogue of online products to include product categories that are not available in-store. As a result, the number of SKUs on each of our store brand websites may grow to substantially exceed the number of SKUs in the corresponding brand’s physical stores. The number of SKUs available on our online stores grew from approximately 35,000 as of January 31, 2018, to approximately 60,000 as of August 2, 2020. We view our digital platform as an extension of our stores. We believe that our opportunities to expand our e-commerce sales are greater in areas where we have brick-and-mortar stores, as e-commerce sales are positively impacted by the convenience of our Click & Collect option. We believe that expanding the number of SKUs available on our store brand websites will be an important competitive advantage because this will increase the accessibility of our product offering and further develop our strategic growth initiatives for our multi-channel platform.

Subsubsection Title: Improving Like-for-Like Sales through employee investment, training and empowerment
Subsubsection Text: Our team members drive our success. As part of our ‘‘Back to Basics’’ strategy, we built commitment through employee investment, training and empowerment including through the launch of a leadership program for store employees and of a training academy for administrative employees, the implementation of an e-learning platform for our employees and the establishment of a new digital human resources management platform. As part of our strategic growth initiatives under our ‘‘Make-it-Easy’’ strategy, we will continue to invest in our workforce and partners with training and individual empowerment, including through (i) the rolling out of a company-wide onboarding program, (ii) the simplification of internal tools such as a digital platform to manage human-resources matters and an internal social network, (iii) increased role-diversification and (iv) the rewarding of internal talents. In addition, we believe that our customers place significant value on technical knowledge and service, and that one of our key advantages is our ability to provide expert advice to our customers across all product categories. Due to our wide range of products, and the highly technical nature of many DIY products, customers increasingly rely on well-trained sales associates to offer knowledgeable assistance in product selection and use. To serve this need, our employees participate in continuous training through our ‘‘Maxeda Academy’’ program, including formal workshops, seminars and certification programs to build technical, managerial and customer service skills. We are also investing in our information technology to introduce online training courses on DIY knowledge for our employees, and we are working with our product suppliers to increase the amount of hands-on training provided to our employees with respect to new products. In addition, we have customer service measurement systems and recognition programs in place for management, sales associates and other employees to measure and encourage overall customer satisfaction. By having more knowledgeable employees, we believe we can offer better customer service and, accordingly, increase our sales.

Subsubsection Title: Refining our three store formats and brands to enhance customer value propositions and accessibility
Subsubsection Text: We seek to continuously improve the customer experience in our stores by adapting to the changing preferences of our target customers and their project requirements. We intend to continue to refurbish stores on a rolling basis to increase revenue and attract new customers through spatial optimization and user-friendly new store layouts. For instance, to strengthen the Praxis brand, we are seeking to improve the customer value propositions by adjusting prices of our products and product ranges at our Praxis City ‘‘City’’ stores and standard Praxis ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores to attract more customers into these stores, which we believe will result in increased sales density and improved profitability, bringing Praxis’s profitability in line with our Brico stores. As of August 2, 2020, we opened 15 stores that apply the new Praxis format, of which four are in Belgium and eleven are in the Netherlands, and refurbished 18 of our stores to reflect this new format, of which nine are in Belgium and nine are in the Netherlands. Furthermore, we plan to continue opening new stores in areas where we do not currently operate. 99 ----- Our ‘‘Make-it-Easy’’ strategy includes certain initiatives through which we intend to continue to refine our store formats to enhance customer value and increase accessibility. Such initiatives include the expansion of our BricoPlanit network to approximately 20 stores from 13 stores. We seek to improve our market-leading positions in Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands by selectively expanding into new local regions and opening additional directly operated stores and franchisee-operated stores that meet our rigorous selection criteria and that will allow us to cover areas that we do not currently serve through brick-and-mortar stores. Furthermore, we aim to increase the accessibility of our stores through selective strategic relocations and facility improvements tailored to the needs of our customers and trends in our markets. For example, we intend to relocate certain stores to better retail locations along highly traveled roads benefiting from higher footfall or visibility. We also anticipate that we will extend the Sunday trading hours at certain of our Belgian stores, to the extent permitted by law, because we believe the weekend allows our customers the greatest opportunity to visit our stores and make in-person purchases. We continue to assess new franchisee-operated stores on a case-by-case basis and monitor our store base to selectively close stores that do not meet our expectations.

Based on our key strengths, our strategic plan currently focuses on growth in revenue and profitability, including through the third phase of our strategic improvement plan, our ‘‘Make-it-Easy’’ strategy, which we launched in 2019 and expect to complete by 2023.

The first Brico store opened in 1973 in Schoten, Belgium. Brico was the first Belgian retailer to offer a broad range of DIY products. In 1978 the first Praxis store opened in Venlo, The Netherlands. Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, we continued to grow both organically and through a number of strategic acquisitions. In 2004, we opened our first BricoPlanit store in Kortrijk, Belgium. In 2006, we opened our first Brico store in Luxembourg and our first Brico City store in Porte de Namur, Brussels. Between 2007 and 2020, we opened numerous stores, growing our store network to 348 stores as of August 2, 2020, under three brands across Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

Subsection Title: Store formats, target customers and store brands
Subsubsection Text: We operate primarily in the Belgian and Dutch DIY markets, and have a small presence in the Luxembourgish DIY market. The top-five DIY retailers in Belgium and the top-seven DIY superstores in the Netherlands had a combined market size of e6.0 billion as of July 2020, according to GfK. The Belgian and Dutch DIY markets are competitive, with various companies such as Gamma, Karwei, Bauhaus and Hornbach in the Netherlands and Hubo, Gamma and Mr. Bricolage in Belgium. While there are also a large number of niche companies and local retailers operating in these markets, we have established a strong position through our multiple store brands and broad range of product offerings. We operate a total of 348 stores, comprising 195 stores in the Netherlands under our Praxis brand, 150 stores in Belgium and three stores in Luxembourg under our Brico and BricoPlanit brands. Until 2019, we operated certain stores in the Netherlands under the Formido brand. We have phased this brand out and all Formido stores have either been closed or converted to Praxis stores. An overview of our three store brands as of August 2, 2020, is set forth in the table below:

We operate three store formats, ‘‘City’’ stores, ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores and ‘‘Big Box’’ stores. Each of our store formats offers a unique focus for its respective target customers: - City Stores: Our ‘‘City’’ stores, consisting of our Brico City and Praxis City stores, are located in city centers. These stores are generally small in size and focus on providing convenient access to products for routine, small-scale maintenance and repair projects. Our ‘‘City’’ stores operate with the following goal: ‘‘We offer a quick and nearby solution for your essential and immediate DIY needs.’’ Our ‘‘City’’ stores target both first-time and more-experienced DIY consumers with basic home repair or improvement needs. Our ‘‘City’’ store customers prioritize convenience and efficiency, often shopping for products for immediate use or those they may have forgotten to purchase during their larger shopping trips. - Mid Box Stores: Our ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores consist of our Brico stores in Belgium and our Praxis stores in the Netherlands. These stores are larger in size and provide a wider range of products for larger maintenance, repair, decoration and renovation projects. Our ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores operate with the following goal: ‘‘Your local trusted everyday store with easy access to regular DIY needs with a solid multi-specialist product offering.’’ 101 10SEP202018085684 ----- Our ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores target both first-time and more-experienced DIY consumers undertaking decorative or home improvement projects that might require more resources than our ‘‘City’’ stores can provide. - Big Box Stores: Our ‘‘Big Box’’ stores consist of our BricoPlanit stores. These stores are our largest, and provide our most extensive range of products for a variety of home improvement projects. Our ‘‘Big Box’’ stores operate with the following goal: ‘‘We are your destination for inspiration and affordable solutions for all your home improvement DIY projects.’’ Our ‘‘Big Box’’ stores primarily target consumers experienced in DIY projects. Our ‘‘Big Box’’ stores are focused on serving consumers shopping for more-technical products for large DIY projects and for more-expensive decorative items, such as lighting fixtures. Our Big Box stores generated e499 million of revenue for the year ended February 2, 2020, e273 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019 and e296 million for the six months ended August 2, 2020. Our City and Mid Box stores together generated e891 million of revenue for the year ended February 2, 2020, e495 million for the six months ended August 4, 2019 and e565 million for the six months ended August 2, 2020. Our customer base spans age and socioeconomic groups, with a higher concentration of our customers being in the 40 to 60 age range.

We pursue a multi-store brand strategy, and operate our stores under the Brico and BricoPlanit brands in Belgium, and the Praxis brand in the Netherlands. Each of our three store brands offers different ranges of products to meet their respective target customers’ preferences and needs. Each of our three store brands carries substantially the same core product categories, with smaller stores carrying a more limited assortment within each product category. Our store brands feature distinct layouts and typically carry between 8,000 and 65,000 SKUs, of which between 4,000 and 29,5000 are typically private label products, depending on the season, store size and store brand. Although we largely standardize assortment and layout among stores of the same store brand, within each we may tailor some stores to the characteristics of a specific geographic area. For example, a store close to a big camping site may offer additional products to cater for camping activities. _Belgium_ In Belgium, we operate a number of different formats across our two store brands: Brico and BricoPlanit. Under the Brico brand, we operate Brico, Briko Depot and Brico City stores that cater to different geographic markets. Under the BricoPlanit store brand, we offer a differentiated ‘‘Big Box’’ store format with extensive ranges that target consumers looking for products for larger DIY projects. Collectively, our Belgian business accounted for 50% of our revenue for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020, including the revenue contribution of our three Brico stores in Luxembourg. We had a market share of 44% of the Belgian DIY Market in terms of Transactional Sales for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. Brico Brico is the DIY market leader in Belgium with a market share of approximately 29% of the Belgian DIY Market in terms of Transactional Sales for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. Brico offers a wide range of DIY, home decoration and garden products, combining third-party branded products with our private label products, with 28,000 to 50,000 SKUs stocked per store. Brico’s three largest product groups are paint, paint specialties and accessories, and hardware. Higher price point garden and wood products drive customer traffic to stores but the demand for garden products varies seasonally. Brico accounted for 31% of our revenue for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. As of August 2, 2020, Brico has a network of 140 stores, including 77 franchisee-operated stores. The average floor surface area of our directly operated stores is approximately 3,300 square meters and the average floor surface area of our franchisee-operated stores is approximately 1,800 square meters. Under the Brico brand, we operate two main types of stores: ‘‘City’’ stores and ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores. Our suburban stores comprise standard Brico stores, which are our largest store type in terms of selling area with a surface area between 1,700 square meters and 7,400 square meters for our directly operated stores, and a surface area between 900 square meters and 4,200 square meters for our franchisee 102 ----- operated stores, as well as our Briko Depot sub-branded store with a surface area of approximately 9,200 square meters, which we still position as a ‘‘Mid Box’’ store format. Our ‘‘City’’ stores comprise our _Brico City sub-branded stores, which as stores in the more confined spaces of city centers, provide for a_ surface area between approximately 300 square meters and 800 square meters, and offer products for smaller DIY jobs and maintenance. During recent years, we have undertaken the expansion of our Brico network through new store openings. Despite existing nationwide coverage, we have identified areas of potential expansion where we do not currently operate any Brico stores. We believe there is potential for two to three Brico store openings per year, either directly operated or franchisee operated. Furthermore, as part of our strategic plan, we intend to refurbish three to four selected Brico stores per year over the next three years and we plan to convert three Brico stores to the BricoPlanit brand. BricoPlanit Under our BricoPlanit store brand, we operate a chain of DIY megastores in Belgium that offer large ranges of products for home improvement projects with approximately 49,000 SKUs per store. While we advertise BricoPlanit to a broad group of consumers, its customer base is skewed towards customers who are more experienced in DIY projects. With our BricoPlanit stores, we mainly focus on customers who are renovating their homes, offering an extensive range of products for home improvement projects, including building materials such as plaster and mortar, as well as wood products, paint and wallpaper. BricoPlanit’s three largest product groups are indoor and construction products, flooring and building materials. BricoPlanit accounted for 19% of our revenue for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. We operate 13 BricoPlanit stores in Belgium under our ‘‘Big Box’’ store format (five stores in Flanders, seven in Wallonia and one in Brussels), all of which we directly operate. Compared with our other store formats and those of our competitors, our BricoPlanit stores are particularly large, with sizes from 6,900 square meters to 11,000 square meters and average floor surface areas of approximately 9,000 square meters. Our sales density at our BricoPlanit stores is the highest in the Belgian DIY market, with approximately e3,000 revenue per square meter. We consistently increased the market share (in terms of Transactional Sales) of our BricoPlanit stores between 2017 and 2020 through improved Like-for-Like Sales and the opening of a new BricoPlanit store in Waterloo, Belgium. For the year ended February 2, 2020, the BricoPlanit brand had a market share of approximately 15% of the Belgian DIY Market by Transactional Sales. We occasionally convert large Brico stores to BricoPlanit stores. _The Netherlands_ In the Netherlands, we operate our stores under the Praxis brand. Our Praxis stores include a range of ‘‘Mid Box’’ stores, with or without a garden center, and Praxis City stores. Until 2019, we operated certain stores in the Netherlands under the Formido brand. We have phased this brand out and all Formido stores have either been closed or converted to Praxis stores. Our Dutch business accounted for 50% of our revenue for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. Praxis Praxis is our leading DIY concept in the Netherlands with a market share of approximately 25% of the Dutch DIY Superstores Market in terms of Transactional Sales as of August 2, 2020, according to GfK. Through our Praxis brand, we employ a multi-channel strategy, adapted to consumers’ different DIY shopping preferences. We offer a broad product assortment ranging between 8,000 to 65,000 SKUs to meet the needs of both experienced and novice DIY enthusiasts. Praxis’s largest product groups are paint, flooring, and indoor and construction products. Higher price point garden and wood products help drive customer traffic to stores. Praxis accounted for 50% of our revenue for the twelve months ended August 2, 2020. Under the Praxis brand, we operate a network of 195 stores across the Netherlands as of August 2, 2020, including 44 franchisee-operated stores, under five sub-brands: Praxis Mega & Garden, with an average surface area of approximately 11,900 square meters; Praxis Mega, with an average surface area of approximately 5,900 square meters; _Praxis City ‘‘City’’ stores, with an average surface area of approximately 300 square meters; and ‘‘standard’’ Praxis stores with an average surface area of 103 ----- approximately 3,000 square meters. The average floor surface area of our standard directly operated Praxis stores is approximately 3,000 square meters and the average surface area of our franchisees’ standard Praxis stores is approximately 2,900 square meters. We have expanded our network of ‘‘City’’ stores in the Netherlands under the Praxis City brand, focusing on a smaller city-specific assortment of products while linking customers digitally to our broader assortment of products. As part of the strategic plan, we have opened ten directly operated Praxis City stores over the past six years. In addition, we have converted a portion of our Formido stores into Praxis stores as part of the phasing out of our Formido brand, refurbishing such stores and the products offered therein to reflect the Praxis brand image. Of the 74 Formido stores that we operated as of January 31, 2018, 40 stores were converted into Praxis stores, 23 stores were sold and the remaining 11 stores were closed.
